name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 5 July 2018.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to say a few thoughts to the victims of the disasters that have struck the Countries of Europe over the last two months. I would like to mention first of all the violent fires in Greece in July, which killed more than ninety people and injured more than two hundred. The fire has also destroyed over a thousand homes and caused enormous environmental and economic damage. Sweden, too, has been the victim of an unprecedented number of devastating fires over the same period, due, among other things, to the high temperatures recorded. Yet another proof of the extent of climate change and the damage caused by global warming. I would like to stress, however, that, thanks to the European civil protection mechanism, it has been possible to support the efforts of the national authorities with firefighters, aircraft and helicopters made available by many countries of the Union. It is an example of concrete solidarity which illustrates the added value of the European Union. Italy, my country, also experienced a dramatic Month of August, with the collapse of the Morandi bridge in Genoa on 14 August, which left 43 people dead and hundreds of families deprived of their homes. I hope that, on the one hand, the administrative and political responsibilities of this serious disaster will be accepted and, on the other hand, that we will be able to proceed quickly with the reconstruction of this structure, which is a fundamental point of passage for the city of Genoa, its port, Italy and the whole of Europe. Genoa is in fact a hub of the European TEN-T networks. That is why the European Union is making available resources for infrastructure of European importance which, together with the Union's regional funds and the European Investment Fund, can be used to improve the city's infrastructure. Unfortunately, a few days after the tragedy of Genoa, also in Italy, a flood of the Raganello stream overwhelmed and killed ten people in the Calabrian province of Cosenza. This sudden flood has also injured many. I hope that the resources that the European Union makes available to the regions can be used to secure tourist sites exposed to natural risks. I would like to express the European Parliament's condolences and our closeness to the families of all the victims of the events that have taken place in Europe in recent months. I would therefore ask you to observe a minute's silence and recollection in order to remember the innocent victims. (Parliament was standing and observing a minute's silence)

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Mr President, I would like to make a point of the regulation on the basis of Article 2 on the independence of our mandate and to the attention of my colleagues that on Thursday 30 August, an official of Parliament, who claims to be acting with a mandate from the Office of the European Parliament to remove false information, asked me to modify a tweet or delete it. A tweet in which I expressed my position on the signing by President Juncker of the JEFTA (EU-Japan Economic Partnership Agreement) without the European Parliament having been consulted beforehand. This official thought she was allowed to threaten me if I did not comply. What does all this mean? That there is a thought police in the European Parliament, mandated to dictate to us, Members, what we are entitled to say and correct what we say? That any criticism of the European Union is now false information? I say to you, ladies and gentlemen, this matter concerns us all, because the freedom of expression of parliamentarians is sacred. You know, Mr President, I like political confrontation, inside and outside the European Parliament, but I will never accept a civil servant telling me what I have to say and interfering in my mandate. You are, Mr President, the guarantor of our rights and I expect you to have an answer, because this case is an extremely serious matter, because it undermines essential principles on the freedom of expression of parliamentarians.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Mr MEP, we will be discussing this subject at the Office meeting this evening.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Mr President, that is what I expected from you. As I told you at the Conference of Presidents, if the facts are true, indeed they are serious. We all have freedom of expression and we have the freedom to defend very different positions, which I hope are always founded in fact, but in any case it is not up to members of the European civil service to correct elected representatives.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the report by Helga Trüpel, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down the legal framework of the European Solidarity Corps and amending Regulations (EU) No 1288/2013, (EU) No 1293/2013, (EU) No 1303/2013, (EU) No 1305/2013, (EU) No 1306/2013 and Decision No 1313/2013/EU (COM(2017)0262 – C8-0162/2017 – 2017/0102(COD) (A8-0060/2018).

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We are now talking about the European Solidarity Corps. It was a very good proposal from the Commission to give young people in the European Union and beyond more opportunities to volunteer, to show solidarity and, overall, to increase solidarity in the European Union. I was very pleased that I was rapporteur, because this is really a new flagship programme, and that is a very positive approach. Not all European Union programmes are considered to be that way. We in Parliament – and this is particularly important to me, as it is also part of our cooperation – have improved this proposal. After all, we have clearly defined what volunteering, volunteering and volunteering really mean. They exist in the social field, in working with refugees, in cultural work, when you support the elderly, or if you are committed to the climate crisis and many more. So it is a great opportunity for young people between the ages of 18 and 30 to do something for themselves by being in other countries, learning languages, getting to know the local conditions, being there in the local communities – that is, being able to develop themselves, in other words, a humanistic approach to education – and at the same time doing something for the community and for the associations. , for the institutions in which they are, by helping other people, because they are convinced that solidarity activities are really good. And then we really made a second point clear: we do not want other companies to kill their jobs afterwards to use this tool. So there should be no abuse. There has also been a very clear clarification. But there should be a small proportion of the new budget, including job opportunities, but definitely not abuse. No young person should suffer from the fact that there is public or European money here and that companies benefit from it.  Then we put a clear focus on disadvantaged young people and, above all, on rural areas. We also know here, among our interns, that the young people who arrive here are usually those who already have a big horizon, who can speak several languages, who have a great education, who are travelling internationally. But not all young people in the European Union are doing this. That is why we must give young people in rural areas or in rural areas, in smaller towns, the opportunity to benefit from these great European offers.  Then, in a fierce dispute with the Council, we managed to get so-called fresh money. This is money that the Member States would otherwise have received back from the European budget, and they have now released it in the order of EUR 75 million, that there is additional money. These are not huge sums, of course, but it is an entry into a new programme that will inspire young people. Even now, a great many people have shown interest. There are new digital application options. But it is also important to me: disadvantaged young people in particular need personal contacts. It's not just digital. You need relationships with people who care about these young people. That is why we have laid this out in our proposal for this European Solidarity Corps. I find it interesting now, politically, that criticism is being voiced from the far left and from the far right. For some it is too European, for others it is somehow not social enough. But the pro-European forces here in this House were very united in favour of this new programme. I would also like to thank all those who have worked with me, especially colleagues, on this programme. It was a great cooperation. Thank you very much! I hope it really will be a great program for young people. They deserve it, and so does the European Union.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it has been an honour to contribute personally to the creation of the European Solidarity Corps, together with Mrs Trüpel and all my colleagues. It has certainly been months of intensive negotiations with the Council and with colleagues from all the political groups. However, I am proud of the result achieved, because it demonstrates Europe's ability to propose concrete and innovative solutions to the challenges of the present. The European Solidarity Corps will enable thousands of girls and boys to put themselves at the service of the people they need most and for the common good. A platform, therefore, for voluntary actions, internships, jobs. I am sure it will be a success, because it is with the energy and enthusiasm of young people that we can succeed in building a better, fairer, more supportive Europe. We will not be poisoned by the hatred and intolerance that imbue the words and actions of xenophobic and nationalist forces. We will not fall into the trap of those who want to dismantle more than half a century of exchanges between our countries, exchanges first of all cultural, human, values – the opposite of a programme – and ideas based on hatred between people and the fight against an idea of a Europe of solidarity, the idea of politicians whom we unfortunately also know in my country, such as Minister Salvini. It is precisely on opposing human and cultural values that the European Solidarity Corps is based, which now requires the involvement of all European, national, social and institutional actors in order to maximise its impact. From the earliest stages of the debate, I have fought for the programme to remain as inclusive as possible, enabling all young Europeans to be able to take part, regardless of their country of origin, their personal needs, their family economic status, with particular attention to young people with disabilities. It was essential to guarantee the principles of equal opportunities, compliance with criteria on the quality of the offers given, the possibility of combining a voluntary path – central to the programme – with a series of measures for work, with adequate remuneration and guaranteed contractual conditions. This so-called employment strand of the programme will make it possible to create partnerships with various socio-economic actors, such as small and medium-sized enterprises, chambers of commerce, social enterprises and cooperatives, while broadening the range of possible actions within it. It was necessary to separate voluntary actions from work better than the Commission's initial proposal, and I believe that work should always be regarded as such, and therefore paid for as such. The text that we will be adopting tomorrow provides important guarantees in this respect. I am pleased to see my proposals becoming part of the new programme. I would therefore like the European Solidarity Corps to prove capable of becoming a powerful means of social cohesion, including intergenerational cohesion, an instrument which, together with Erasmus and the Social Fund, will be able to help the many organisations that are fighting to do good where it is most needed, especially many youth organisations. An instrument, for example, which, in tragic situations, such as the collapse of the Morandi bridge in Genoa, which we mentioned just today, will make it possible to activate girls and boys from all over Europe who want to roll up their sleeves to help, as was already done in the experimental phase also in Norcia. In short, a tangible example of a Europe of solidarity. A Europe of solidarity is the Europe of the future.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, having followed the work on the European Solidarity Corps on behalf of the ENVI Committee, and having worked on the opinion of the ENVI Committee as rapporteur, I must say that I looked with great interest at a project that could put the issue of solidarity, the idea of solidarity, back at the centre, in putting together a body of young Europeans who were concerned with solidarity. Unfortunately, this initial thrust has not been maintained, and I say this above all in the light of the outcome of the trialogue. Trilogy that has again diverted funds to "profit" organizations, a trilogy after which we continue in a very dangerous overlap between volunteering and poorly paid work, precarious work. I want to point out something else and then I really close, Mr President. I believe that excluding migrants, asylum seekers and environmental refugees from a programme of this kind is the disappearance of the spirit of integration and cooperation that should have been at the heart of this programme.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I am glad to join you on the eve of your final vote on the regulation providing the European Solidarity Corps with a dedicated legal base. I want to express my thanks for the great dedication with which Parliament has handled this file. My particular thanks go to the rapporteur, Ms Trüpel, and her shadow rapporteurs. For the Commission, the proposal to create a European Solidarity Corps is a major component of our commitment to invest in young people. Together with Erasmus+ the Solidarity Corps will be instrumental in creating new opportunities for young people – opportunities to learn, to engage for causes important to them, to support others and to help us build a resilient cohesive Europe for the future. Most importantly, the European Solidarity Corps can offer young people the chance to experience what it feels like to be European. At a time of rising discord and widening cultural gaps between countries and even within communities, this is more important than ever. The Solidarity Corps also shows how Europe can act and take responsibility. Together with Parliament and Council we have moved swiftly to make it a reality. Now we have the duty not to disappoint the many young people who have come forward to join the Corps. More than 75 000 young people have already registered in the European Solidarity Corps portal and over 8 000 have started their activities on the ground, and the numbers keep rising. With the new regulation, and the budget which goes with it, we will be able to offer solidarity opportunities to 100 000 young people by 2020. But the new regulation you will be voting on tomorrow only covers the years up to 2020. Sending a strong signal to Europe’s young people, the Commission has proposed to strengthen and further expand the European Solidarity Corps in the next long-term EU budget from 2021 to 2027. We want to consolidate and build on what we already have during this period, with one important novelty: we propose to also support volunteering for humanitarian aid operations. This can be the start of creating a truly global volunteering community. The European Solidarity Corps is a flagship project for Europe’s youth. It therefore needs ambitious funding. That is why we have proposed to raise the budget to EUR 1.26 billion over the seven years. This will enable us to offer 350 000 solidarity opportunities by 2027. I count on the support of this House, and especially of the rapporteur, Ms Šojdrová. Let us work together to make sure we find a swift agreement on how to develop the Corps for the future. Young people have a crucial role in building the future. With next year’s European Parliament elections coming closer, further strengthening the European Solidarity Corps will send an important signal that we are putting that future in their hands. Thank you again for your support.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Mr President, I would like to thank the Since the creation of the European Voluntary Service 22 years ago, one hundred thousand Europeans have participated in this programme. The European Voluntary Service is now to become even more attractive, and we have the ambitious objective of adding another hundred thousand participants, and I think that is a good ambition that we have.  For us as the S&D Group, it was important that we defend the non-profit principle of this program in order to ensure the charitable nature of the activities. It was also important to make a clear distinction between voluntary commitment and professional work in order to prevent the use of voluntary service in order to displace jobs. As the S&D Group, it was particularly important to us that the money for this programme is indeed fresh money, and it is good that we have managed to get at least twenty per cent fresh money, that there is transparency in the reallocation of funds and that there is no negative impact on other programmes and funds, such as the Erasmus+ programme.  With regard to funding and as a member of the Committee on Budgets, however, I must also make it quite clear at this point that, unfortunately, it has become apparent that the Member States are not prepared to actually provide fresh, new money for new projects. In my view, the Council and the Commission have also acted somewhat irresponsibly in this project, which is so important for young Europeans. It is simply not acceptable for the Council to publicly announce that there is a new programme and then not to provide the money for it! The Commission, too, has not been completely tarnished with glory. It has developed the new programme, but has not ensured that the funding of this programme does not jeopardise other existing programmes. And the funding of this sensible programme has, in the end, once again made it clear that the European Union must be worth a little more to the Member States than it is now.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am pleased that an agreement has been reached in the course of the interinstitutional negotiations on this important project. I think we all agree on the importance of stimulating pro-social attitudes, empathy and a sense of solidarity for the good functioning of society. I am convinced that the European Solidarity Corps could soon become one of the eu's most important tools for promoting these values among young people. However, the European Solidarity Corps is not only volunteering, but also traineeships and employment in areas related to the idea of solidarity. As an opinion-giver on this proposal in the Committee on Employment, I supported this proposal from the outset and I am pleased that this pillar has also been preserved in the final agreement. Many European Union countries are still facing high youth unemployment, which is why I believe that any new opportunity for professional development and every additional job is at a premium.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture, I would like to set out the most important elements of our position. Among other things, we have highlighted the need for a greater focus on young people in rural areas, who usually have difficult access to such initiatives. The rapporteur has spoken about this. We stressed the importance of training, which in our opinion should be an integral part of the project and an opportunity to exchange best practices in the field of agriculture and rural development. We have also proposed increasing the financial component for traineeships and employment from 20% to 25% and have expressed the view that volunteering should not be a substitute for paid work. Finally, we have indicated that if other EU policies are used for the corps, they should reflect the objectives of the original budget line. The European Solidarity Corps provides an opportunity to strengthen young people's attachment to the European project and to acquire valuable skills and experiences useful on the labour market.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, we are going to approve a new European programme for young people, with a significant budget and impact as has been mentioned: EUR 375 600 000 over three years, targeting 100 000 young people. It is a huge programme and I am glad to confirm that the EPP Group will support the trilogue agreement to be voted on tomorrow. More opportunities for youth volunteer activities will be available in Europe, as well as new internships and jobs in the solidarity sector. The key principles in this context are the European added value of the activities; no overlapping with national schemes; and the principle of non-profitability. We managed to strike a good deal with the Council in the middle of the financial framework. This was difficult as we had to find the necessary resources without harming existing programmes, in particular Erasmus +. We have achieved this outcome only because, as representatives of the political groups, we stood united with our rapporteur, Helga Trüpel. There was a consensus among us on other issues, such as the emphasis on continuity with the European Voluntary Service and the perception of volunteering as a key part of the programme. That is why I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteur for their excellent cooperation. I look forward to cooperating with our colleagues and with the Commissioner on the next programme.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I believe the European  Solidarity Corps is an interesting and timely initiative which gives young people the chance to take part in projects that will benefit communities across Europe. It is, in part, a response to the outpouring of compassion shown by many young people in response to numerous natural disasters, such as devastating floods in my region, and to the refugee crisis. The initiative is a unique chance to strengthen the European dimension of volunteering, hopefully enabling exchange of best practices among Member States and encouraging wider promotion of active participation and volunteering at national level.  However, I must take this opportunity to reaffirm the key role of citizenship, education and active participation of young – and less young – people more generally, and the importance of properly supporting all relevant initiatives in this field through the next EU budget. Citizenship, education and active participation facilitate intercultural dialogue, and promote personal and collective development and wellbeing and empowerment of individuals and communities. We must prepare a generation of young people with the motivation, commitments and skills, including critical and creative thinking, so that they can be audacious problem solvers and responsible citizens in a more fair and inclusive world. Following the Charlie Hebdo and Danish attacks in 2015, the 28 EU Education Ministers signed the Paris Declaration calling for the use of education and active participation to promote fundamental values. I was proud to be given the responsibility of writing a report for Parliament’s Committee on Culture and Education on this topic, making many concrete recommendations. We now have a historic opportunity to implement these recommendations and provide citizenship initiatives with proper funding. But promoting our fundamental values through dialogue, diversity and education is a shared responsibility of societies, and all stakeholders must be included in that strategy. The next EU budget must, therefore, also properly recognise the key role of civil society and organisations working at grass roots level and provide them with appropriate support and resources.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Dear Chairman, I apologize, but I didn't answer.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the European Solidarity Corps strengthens previous volunteer programmes, adapting them to current circumstances. Today there are Eurosceptic currents that seek to undermine the building of solidarity that we are creating. But young people, who are the great Europeanists, will not allow it. Through this program they will be able to provide altruistic help or work where they are most needed; you will gain valuable experience that will be able to serve you in your professional career. Very important: young people who will meet other young people and create a pattern of affections that will make them more European and strengthen our Union. These programs are not secondary or accessories between European programmes. Economics, transport, finance... all of this is very important; but solidarity and friendship are the vital fabric that Europe will sustain.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the much-advertised European Solidarity Corps by Mr Juncker and the Commission is, in my view, a continuation of the multifaceted attack of the neoliberal European Union on all social sectors and the false coverage of real needs. The concepts of solidarity and volunteering are used only euphemisticly and we have seen what this means within the European Union: it means exempting the state from the obligation to provide social services, reducing paid jobs and replacing them with voluntary work in the Middle Ages. The European Solidarity Corps is, in essence, another ideological and political mechanism under the control of the Commission, it is a limited undertaking that can neither effectively deal with the disastrous consequences of neoliberal policies nor respond to the enormous social and economic problems and social needs. The economic crisis, unemployment, precarious work and migration of young people are not dealt with by individual action and private initiative. Europe's young people do not need to support supposed actions of volunteering and solidarity, but to boost real spending on public education and to create quality jobs, with full employment rights, so that they can start their lives with dignity and build a real solidarity future for the peoples of Europe.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, while supporting the purpose of the new programme, I cannot fail to highlight some critical points that the Italian Government has also noted and which we will not fail to correct in the Commission's new proposal for the 2021-2027 programming. Firstly, I am not convinced by the decision to break this new programme away from Erasmus+, because Erasmus+ remains the best known and most loved programme in European youth policies. Secondly, only non-profit-making organisations should be allowed to participate in the programme and receive funding, otherwise we risk finding ourselves multinationals engageed just to clean up their image, and also using public money. Finally, I am sceptical about the presence of the employment side. The tragedy of youth unemployment is well known and requires serious labour policies. By mixing the concepts of volunteering and work, we are debasing volunteering on the one hand and increasing opportunities for labour exploitation and substitution on the other, and also increasing the precarious situation that we must fight with conviction.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, from the very first lines, the tone is set: it is to ward off the rise of Euroscepticism that a few thousand volunteers will come to speak the good word and enlarge the ranks of NGOs that are already scouring the reefs of the Mediterranean. In addition to its bias, the aim of this umpteenth baldness pompously dubbed the "European Body of Solidarity" is all too obvious. For, not to the displeasure of the Commission, the temptation to remove some young people from the embarrassing unemployment figures is not new, nor is it the temptation to target disadvantaged audiences. Emmanuel Macron has already given in this summer by opening civic service to some 5,000 refugees a year. Unsurprisingly, young Working-class Europeans will pay a high price for this foreign preference, since Erasmus' budget is cut. However, as a crucial electoral deadline approaches, France and europe of the forgotten will be keen to remind Brussels that it is only dependent on the will of the people.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we are discussing the establishment of the European Solidarity Corps. Fate wants it to coincide just two years after President Juncker's announcement during the State of the Union debate. In my role as shadow rapporteur for the opinion report of the Committee on the Environment, I tried to transfer the need for the FUNDS of the LIFE programme, which will be earmarked for the construction of this Corps – some four and a half million – to be earmarked for environmental-related Solidarity Corps activities. Mitigating the effects of the most extreme temperatures, fires, floods, etc. will be the very important tasks that this Corps will carry out, recovering one of the founding values of the European Union that we have today: solidarity. Solidarity between Europeans is not that in the institutions we cover ourselves with the shames between the Member States. Solidarity is expressed, as President Juncker said in that debate, when Portuguese forests burn and help them shut down Italian aircraft; when Croatia and light generators are flooded, they are Swedish. If we do not return the sense of community, to belong to something greater than our small or great state, if we do not try to return that idea that any impact that a European receives will resonate in the hearts and souls of all Europeans, we will hardly be able to regain the path to the Union devised by its builders.  Bono once said that we had to move from the idea of Europe to the feeling of Europe. I sincerely believe, Mr President, that with this report we are going in this good direction.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate this Union on the investment in strengthening the European Solidarity Corps programme, open to all young people in Europe. This programme will enable young Europeans to provide support to communities in need through voluntary actions, internships or employment. In a time of uncertainty, with populist and xenophobic discourses within our borders, the commitment to a European Solidarity Corps is fundamental to countering this return to a past that should embarrass us all. It is with these initiatives that European citizenship is consolidated and young people are inspired to believe in this project. We are now giving them what they deserve most: on the one hand, a job opportunity and, on the other hand, we are reinforcing in them what many fear, the love of Europe, the love of the other by volunteering. We know that one in four young Europeans has participated in a volunteer activity during the last two months, which demonstrates the spirit of fraternity of our youth. And I am particularly happy to know that my country, Portugal, is the third country in the Union with the most candidates for the European Solidarity Corps. Strengthen solidarity and focus on the future, that is, on youth. It will be they, young people from all over Europe, who will make what appears to be a forsafore-threatened project solid. I say "it seems" because the desire for freedom is stronger than the walls and prisons that have been erected. And it will be they, the young people, who bring them down. Helping others is what defines us as men, but also as Europeans. A good-being for the young people of this Europe.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Mr President, the European Solidarity Corps is a scheme dreamt up by Mr Juncker immediately after the United Kingdom voted to leave the European Union. In his State of the Union speech two years ago, Mr Juncker admitted the EU was at a low ebb and sprayed around half-baked ideas for new programmes in the manner of an out-of-control machine gun. Two years on, one would have hoped that cooler heads would have prevailed, because this is a knee-jerk idea that will not achieve the purpose for which it was devised, which is boosting levels of European consciousness in member nations. But it certainly will risk unfairly crowding out the many excellent youth volunteer schemes that already exist within those nations, and at a cost to European taxpayers running into hundreds of millions of euros. In my own country, the National Citizen Service and the world-renowned Duke of Edinburgh Award Scheme stand to suffer unfair EU-subsidised competition. Perhaps one could coin the phrase ‘solidarity dumping’ to describe the phenomenon. I would also like to sound a note of caution about one of the main activities that was envisaged for this scheme, namely to have young, idealistic Europeans working to assist newly-arrived asylum seekers, who are overwhelmingly young men from societies riddled with violence and in which core European values such as gender equality are not well observed. The risks entailed in having untrained European teenagers working in proximity with often traumatised new arrivals should be obvious. Another weakness of the Corps is that it threatens entirely to smother two pre-existing smaller schemes, namely the European Voluntary Service, and EU Aid Volunteers. In the autumn of 2016, a Commission that felt humiliated by the Brexit vote and alarmed by a public backlash against its approach on immigration and asylum, decided to make up programmes on the hoof. It would actually send out a message that Mr Juncker has calmed himself and is no longer in such a blind panic were he now to pull the plug on this folly. After all, polling evidence indicates that it’s not starry-eyed school-leavers who have lost faith in the EU, but rather their more experienced and worldly-wise parents after many years of suffering Commission power grabs that undermine their quality of life, particularly in the fields of monetary policy and migration. This scheme was always more about propaganda than public spiritedness and it should be scrapped.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Solidarity is good, in voluntary action much better, and the whole thing in a corps is best. Volunteering can serve as an educational and orientation period for young people. At the same time, however, it must not happen that volunteers, if they no longer like the task, can simply stop. Finally, there is also a need for further training in character. This is the case when you have to fight your way through difficult situations. Another aspect: career promotion. Here, too, a differentiated approach must be taken. EU-subsidised wages must not lead to volunteers being used as a free substitute for regular workers. Earlier this year, the Commission had a peculiar idea of signing a contract with UEFA, which provided for solidarity corps volunteers as free assistants for the forthcoming European Football Championship. It's nice for UEFA, but bad for taxpayers. We would subsidise a multi-million dollar company, and that certainly cannot be in the sense of a solidarity corps.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. I will not hide that with this program was not easy. Firstly, there was a lack of legal basis at the outset, which the Committee on Culture had to deal with for more than half a year. Secondly, the collection of these funds was carried out at all times with a great degree of uncertainty as to the programme which was still in place at the moment. Fortunately, everything ended well, we have a 20% increase in funding for the work of young volunteering – which I am very happy about. There has been some consensus on the committee between the various political forces to ensure that the programme is well defined, well described and well publicated, because it is important that young people simply know about it, know how to use it. Finally, I will say only one thing, one demand – a new budget line must be established as soon as possible, new financial conditions for the next perspective, this is very, very urgent.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, in order to justify its failure on two very serious issues, youth work and the provision of social service to citizens, the european Union's leadership is trying to confuse and mislead young people and refers to the need for voluntary work to supposedly promote solidarity. How this circle perceives solidarity is all you have to do is look at the case of Greece, where the people are impoverished and the youth unemployment rate is at an unseen high. Of course, voluntary work, when properly implemented, is a sign of solidarity, but in order for a young person to deal with issues and issues of solidarity he must first have secured his own work, his or her family's livelihood. Then he'll find a way to express his love for the rest of society. That is why I believe that the debate we are having here is meaningless and that, when young people realise this, they will realise, once again, that their purity has been exploited.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, the concepts are once again being misrepresented and falsified. You are wearing illegal immigration under the cloak of solidarity against European citizens! It is not solidarity to offer young people as far north to NGOs, by volunteering as a substitute for an otherwise paid position, by making excuses to some deft people for enrichment and by grabbing national and Community funds. It is not solidarity to allow so-called third-country volunteers to settle in Europe under the pretext of voluntary work, dictating the facilitation of the issue of residence permits at the expense of respect for security, legality and equality in procedures. It is not solidarity to support third countries and forget your own citizens who suffer from your economic policies. I am against any phobic ideological syndrome and those who are ashamed to accept that we must promote the interests of our own citizens. At last, show solidarity with the European family and not with every illegal intruder!

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Thank you very much. I, too, would like to clarify a concept that has been repeatedly mentioned here in the debate, including the rapporter, who said that the pro-Europeans will surely support young people volunteering in other Member States, but the anti-Europeans will certainly not support it.  Dear Mrs Rapportőr, dear Fellow Members, We are not anti-European, we are opposed to the United States of Europe plan. We love Europe very much, we love European values, but we believe in a Europe of nations, and we love and value European values so much that we defend them. For example, my country, Hungary, has to do so by protecting the Hungarian borders, protecting the Schengen borders and saying no to mass migration. Let us therefore clarify the concepts: we are not anti-European, we are pro-European, but we are opposed to both mass migration and the plan of the United States of Europe. Thank you!

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me first thank you for the overwhelming support for the draft regulation, and let me also thank again Ms Trüpel for her work and for the collaboration on this topic. The European Solidarity Corps is at the moment a potential, an opportunity, to make European solidarity a reality. I think that, with the legal base and with solid funding, we can implement very successful projects, and I hope that these projects will convince all those MEPs who are sceptical at the moment, or even hostile to this project. The European Solidarity Corps is not a state-building process, it is not an artificial community. It simply helps young people to find opportunities – either in their own countries or in other EU Member States – to help people who may have been struck by natural disasters or who live in need, or to find friends in communities and to build a network of volunteers who are willing to help and support other people and other communities. That is what the European Solidarity Corps is all about. I do not know why there should be such concern that it is contrary to young people’s interests, or something like that. I think it is a good opportunity and I hope that the future will convince you too that it is a good and useful opportunity.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I want to thank all my colleagues who have supported this new programme, and I would like to stress that there is no risk to Erasmus+. In fact, it is the other way round. As we heard, there is 20% fresh money, so it’s about additional possibilities for young people and, as I said before, especially disadvantaged youngsters. I think this programme represents a very good combination: giving more possibilities to young people in Europe and beyond, with more money and more opportunities for self-development, and at the same time more opportunities to serve their communities in very different fields. This will be another flagship programme, I hope, alongside Erasmus+. So it is not a matter of contradiction or of competition; no, it’s the other way round. It’s really a win-win situation. It is very interesting for me, from a political perspective, to hear the arguments against. To the Brexiteers and Ms Morvai I would say that I know, to some extent, you cannot think in terms of supranational democracy. You think that democracy works only in a nation state but, you know, the European Union, for decades has now, has proved that there is a very good combination of local, regional, national and supranational democracy, and that is what I will defend because that is the future. Believe me, we have had such a bad history with nationalism all over Europe and we should not go back to this bad sort of nationalism. Yet when I listen to you, you are so filled with hate and resentment. When young people work with refugees, it is a very good contribution to solidarity. This is not about mass immigration and so on: it’s about solidarity and being responsible for people who are poor, who are in need. The fact that young people are ready to do that, and that we enable them to do it and to develop their capacities, reflects a good European attitude. I like it, and I thank all who support this programme. To get the budget up, and then, hopefully with the next Multiannual Financial Framework, to go beyond one billion would be a good proof of European-ness.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 11 September 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – I am pleased that the legal framework of the European Solidarity Corps has finally been completed and that the programme can officially start operating. The programme will include projects based on solidarity on education, health, the environment and disaster prevention.  A total of EUR 375.6 million will be available for the period 2018-2020, of which 90% will be dedicated to voluntary projects and 10% to the work part of the programme. The programme will also be available to young people who otherwise have fewer opportunities, such as people with disabilities or isolated and marginalised communities, people with learning or health problems, the European Commission and the Member States will prepare individualised information and opportunities. I am pleased that volunteering and voluntary projects continue to be supported by the European Union.  It is important to motivate young people and enable them to become involved in as many programmes as possible, which also have a community-building role.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Ruža Tomašić, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) 2017/825 to increase the financial envelope of the structural reform support programme and adapt its overall objective (COM(2017)0825 - C8-0433/2017 - 2017/0334(COD)) (A8-0227/2018).

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Rapporteur. – Dear Chair, colleagues and colleagues, the different starting positions of the Member States are still an important cause of their unequal development today. But in this time of universal technological progress, in which the whole world, including its most underdeveloped parts, is richer than ever, in Europe we should have been much easier to overcome the initial inequalities. Unfortunately, this did not happen or happen slowly. Because less developed members did not possess precious know-how at the beginning of their European path, and some of them did not understand the importance of structural reforms. Today, as Members of the Union, they use various mechanisms to gather the knowledge needed for reforms, but the reform processes themselves often have nowhere to finance. Any real reform saves money in the long run because it makes processes faster, employees more efficient and educated, and services to citizens better, but its implementation costs money. This is why this structural reform support programme is extremely important.  Increasing the financial envelope from €142.8 to a total of as much as €300 million is a guarantee that the programme will be able to support the reform efforts of each Requesting Member State. This is particularly important in the context of the new recession that our economies will face in the near future. There is no better preparation for the crisis than structural reforms, and that is why we must support members in their efforts to implement them, and where awareness does not exist we need to make additional efforts. When it comes to the new recession, which is a normal part of any business cycle, it is important to note that we have also amended Article 4 by including support to prepare for access to the euro area among the objectives of the Programme. This will ensure that all members wishing to join the euro meet all the criteria and are more resilient to the crisis in order to avoid some of the difficult scenarios we witnessed in the last recession. My personal priority when working on this report was to ensure that the increase in the financial envelope was not done to the detriment of cohesion policy, which is already under great fire. Cohesion Policy is a key mechanism for strengthening the capacity of less developed countries and reducing disparities between member states and we must preserve it in its current form. I am satisfied with the solution reached that an increase of up to €222.8 million is achieved through the use of flexibility instruments, while a further 77.2 million can be achieved through the transfer of funds from the budget for technical assistance at the request of member states. Another aspect of this proposal that I must highlight is the involvement of the local community in the implementation of reforms. In accordance with the constitutional and administrative organisation of a Member State, local and regional authorities should be involved in the reform process. I think this is very important so that reforms are tailor-made for people, not bureaucracy, and that funding them would be as transparent as possible. Since October this year is the deadline for submitting projects that should be financed from the Programme in 2019, I have personally engaged to inform stakeholders from Croatia. I encourage, of course, everyone else to conduct a comprehensive outreach campaign for all stakeholders as soon as possible so that the funds are fully used. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank all my colleagues who have contributed through their work on the committees to this report and all those who will support it in the vote.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, structural reforms are crucial to modernise our economies, strengthen their performance and resilience and foster real convergence within and across Member States. The crisis has shown that given the high level of integration of EU economies, reform efforts are a matter of common concern. Your vote tomorrow will be a signal that we stand by Member States in these efforts, and it will be an important step in finalising the package of proposals for deepening economic and monetary union. Structural reforms not only create an environment that is conducive to investment growth and job creation, they can also help EU economies withstand shocks and contribute to economic and social cohesion. This is why structural reforms are important building blocks for a more resilient economic and monetary union. Since May 2017 we have been supporting the design and implementation of structural reforms in Member States through the structural reforms support programme (SRSP). This has proven its usefulness, judging from the number of requests from Member States which significantly exceeded the current budget possibilities. This year 24 Member States applied for an amount that was five times the available budget. To respond to the growing demand from Member States we need to increase the funding. At the same time, to strengthen the euro it will be beneficial to provide targeted support to those Member States wishing to adopt the euro, in order to help them to prepare better and facilitate their smooth participation in economic and monetary union. This is why on 6 December 2017 we proposed to increase the budget of SRSP by EUR 80 million. Throughout the legislative process both the Parliament and the Council have shown a clear commitment to EU support for structural reforms in the Member States. The compromise that we found is a good one. Half of the increase of EUR 80 million will be funded by the global margin for commitments, the other half will be funded through redeployment available from Heading 2, not affecting the rural and development programmes, nor technical assistance. This means that we are fully respecting the commitment from the original SRSP regulation not to provide further financing for the programme at the expense of cohesion policy. I want to thank the European Parliament, the rapporteur Ms Tomašić, the shadow rapporteurs, and the committee chair, Ms Mihaylova, for the hard work and constructive efforts during the trilogue negotiations. Honourable Members, by endorsing the political agreement tomorrow you will move Europe one step closer to a more integrated, more resilient and more cohesive economic and monetary union. The swift adoption of this file will also enable us to increase our support for reforms in Member States already as of next year.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, many Member States struggle with reduced administrative capacities and lack of know-how to implement well-designed public policies. It was the acknowledgement of this fact that led to the establishment of the Structural Reform Support Programme (SRSP) back in 2017. As a bottom-up tool entailing little administrative burden, the SRSP can play a very important role in implementing reforms that push for convergence, reduce disparities and increase administrative capacity. It can also be instrumental in creating the conditions for smarter and more efficient deployment and absorption of EU funds. In the time that has passed since its adoption, the programme has already proven to be a popular and useful instrument in Member States. Given the positive initial results, I strongly support both the reinforcement of the programme’s budget as well as the Commission’s proposal to endow it with its own EUR 25 billion budget in the next Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Ms Maletić is not here and I will speak on behalf of the PPE Group in the same time slot. The Structural Reform Support Programme is the new kid on the block. It is a new instrument that started with the support of Parliament. I was one of the rapporteurs in this period. We started with a tiny amount of EUR 42 million, and the success of this programme, the take—up by Member States – 24 of them, as you said – means that these structural reforms are considered necessary, which is exactly what rapporteur Ruža Tomašić told us. It is important to say yes to the second step and start immediately in October with the call, but I must say, Commissioner, your happiness is okay, but you put forward another proposal to take even more money from the performance reserve. I can say that this second step, the second legal proposal here, will be the last on this in this period, and your next step will be in the next MFF. There you have up to EUR 25 billion for a bigger rollout of the idea and of the three instruments that you proposed, so we are very happy, the PPE Group strongly supports it. It is necessary, it works, and it makes Europe better.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank Mrs Tomašić for her report. We support the report and we also support the programme, which has been a good success, but we also do so with the need that this reform should not primarily damage the social rights of European citizens and lead to structural reforms that are socially responsible. We need structural reforms that promote sustainable growth, in addition to the social issues I have already mentioned, and that is why we need to combine national efforts with the support, when necessary, of the European institutions as well. Structural reforms must be carried out because they serve to make the economy stronger, but they cannot be a lock-in with which to undermine citizens' rights. They must be done as quickly as possible, but always in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, and they must be coordinated with the specific programmes and objectives of the Structural Funds and therefore of the specific policies of the various countries on the basis, as I said, of the principle of subsidiarity. Furthermore, it is essential that this programme remains voluntary, that is to say, at the disposal of the states that are asking for it. Of course, at the end of this mandate, we will be able to go into further detail and assess its efficiency for the next programming period as well.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr. Chairman, I want to express my full support to the rapporteur at the outset of these proposals she put forward in today's debate and, of course, underline that these 300 million that we have in this envelope can really help those countries that really want reforms because maybe some governments don't want reforms. But those who want will certainly have support in this, especially when we talk about joining the euro, we know about the problems that were when the euro was accessed and when some members joined the euro. We have those who want to join the euro, but, of course, they can also have appropriate difficulties in their structural reforms. That's why I think it's extremely important that we're on the trail of supporting this report. I also want to stress the importance of reform and assistance to local and regional self-government because there is life there, in municipalities, cities, in the regions is life, first and foremost. And precisely by respecting the principle of subsidiarity and helping those states that want to reform their regional and local system, I think this envelope is extremely important.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, dear colleagues, dear Commissioner. Just one and a half years ago in May 2017, we adopted the Structural Reform Support Programme for 2017 to 2020. Back then, one of the main points of critique of this House was the financing of the programme from the Cohesion Policy envelope. Structural reforms are a very wide subject. In the past, they have been used for many different things and many different things have been called structural reforms. The aim of cohesion policy however, and the aim of cohesion money thus, is actually pretty well defined. It means to strengthen economic and social cohesion by reducing disparities in the level of development between regions. Now, nearly one and a half years later, we need to amend the SRSP. But again, no fresh money is being mobilised from the EU budget to fill the financing gap. Instead, again, redeployment shall fix this. This time, up to EUR 40 million from heading two – so money foreseen for agriculture and natural resources – shall be redeployed. This is not acceptable for my group. Additionally, the outcome of the negotiation leaves one important question unanswered: if money is short, which requests should get support of the programme? We proposed some pretty clear criteria to make the process more transparent, but the compromise in the outcome is rather meaningless and actually leaves a lot of discretion to the Commission to arbitrarily make a choice among the requests for support from the Member States. This is why we cannot support this report in its current form.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I absolutely disagree with this proposal to downplay cohesion policy in favour of increasing funds by a very considerable percentage to implement structural reforms which are only bringing dire consequences of austerity to most citizens, of the population. Under this beautiful name as the 'programme to support structural reforms' are hidden strategies of precarization of employment, privatization of public assets, competitiveness measures... et cetera; which, as is being demonstrated, dress very well the global data of the economy but without actually reaching the pocket of citizens. As if that were not enough, the proposal put forward by our group, the GUE/NGL, to include tax evasion and the fight against poverty in the objectives of the programme has been eliminated by the Council. It is yet a demonstration that what matters to this European Union is more than anything the big numbers and not how wealth is distributed among the population. More cohesion policy and less structural reform. More distribution of wealth and less concentration of capital.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last year the delegation of the 5-Star Movement opposed, both in committee and in plenary, the establishment of this programme to support structural reforms. On this specific text, which proposes the adaptation of the objective and the increase in the budget, we cannot once again fully support it, even if the 80 million proposed do not come from cohesion policy. But let us be clear: structural reforms, precisely according to the definition taken up in this regulation, also mean those relating to the labour market, and therefore to social security, the liberalisation and privatisation of services, not to mention the field of education and training. We are not and will never agree on these.  On the other hand, we agree on reforms such as simplifying public procurement legislation or combating money laundering, measures to combat social inclusion and the fight against poverty, such as citizenship income. The European Union must therefore pay attention to the political direction of structural reforms and what it imposes on the Member States. It is true that membership of the programme is optional. But are you sure that all states, such as the Italian Government, will implement the reforms that will have the only direction, namely the common good, and not that of supporting private individuals and lobbies? We are not certain at all.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, during the recess I met a gentleman in the Netherlands and he asked me: 'Where does this money from these cohesion funds actually come from, where is it going and how is it controlled?' Then I said, "Well, I can answer the first two questions. That money comes from you, you're the taxpayer. The Dutch government collects these taxes and the Dutch government transfers that money to the EU, to Brussels. And Brussels is transferning it back to, for example, Bulgaria."  But then it's going to be hard. Because who controls that? That's not the Dutch government. This gentleman has a little faith in that. It is not the EU, he is already a lot less confident. No, it is the Bulgarian government that does that. That's no chance, i can't explain it.  It's even easier for me to explain to my wife how offside works in football or to explain that Rocky and Rambo are not the same, but also a bit. But it cannot be explained that a taxpayer in the Netherlands is not bothered here in the EU to control the money he earns and that is spent in Bulgaria.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: Mr President, I thank our fellow rapporteur for trying to give the matrix of this programme a more close base to cohesion policy.  That doesn't mean I'm reassured.  I even wonder about the purpose of such a program, especially when it is financially based on regional policy. Indeed, the liberal objectives it pursues are not those of economic, social and territorial cohesion to which our Parliament is so attached. I also observe with fear the amplification of this drift with the proposals on the next multi-year financial framework, in which the Commission proposes to endow this programme with an envelope of 22 billion euros, thus endorsing the dismantling of cohesion policy. Ladies and gentlemen, we must not choose a Europe that would turn away from the development of our territories in favour of a Europe that encourages the liberalisation of labour markets and the dismantling of health systems. Do you want to make that choice? I don't believe it.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: Mr President, it is very good that many European countries have found the way to the structural reform support programme. This support programme is a real European success. It creates jobs for people, it tackles environmental problems and ensures sound public finances. I am therefore pleased that we are increasing the budget to help countries with their much-needed reforms. In this way, money that we then invest from the European budget there, in those countries, can actually start to pay off. If you have the best with your country and with Europe, then you need to support structural reforms.  The occasional coalition of nationalists, populists and extremists who reject the proposal tomorrow will vote against their own national interest. That has very little to do with patriotism, but that has everything to do with political short-sightedness.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, the structural reform support programme has a history and has existed in Greece since 2015, as my country is supported in the design and implementation of structural reforms. However, it should be stressed that, as this programme is voluntary, we can see three conditions that will make the programme friendlier and more effective. The first is for the proposed reforms to have a development sign, i.e. to emphasise the removal of obstacles, such as bureaucracy and the unfavourable institutional framework, but also to provide facilities for innovative financial instruments. The second is to make the word "reforms" more creative and less imposing. For example, in education, in public health, changes are needed that will give citizens opportunities and good services so that citizens can embrace reforms. The third is to remember that a suit does not make for everyone. That is why the programme must also have a national sign, meet the needs of each country and meet them. In this way the reforms will work and the money of European taxpayers leaving cohesion will take hold.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Cohesion policy is one of the most important. Within cohesion policy, we have many priorities, both those that have been critical and those that have been positive, which I share. What I am most pleased about in these declarations, which have emerged recently, is that between 2018 and 2021, the first of the real events will be monitoring the impact of the funds spent under this priority, and I must say that I was surprised to find that until now such precise, accurate monitoring was unfortunately not. Once again, it is very good that, in this next three-year perspective, Parliament will be informed of the effects of spending money under this priority.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Thank you very much. Dear Colleagues, I am so sorry that the taxi driver who took me to the airport in Budapest this morning, a young man in his 40s, asked me: Krisztina, is it true that we, our age group, will no longer have a pension? Is it true that Europe is going in this direction? And you also asked, how is it true that there will be no social security-based health care now? That it's going to be private health care?  And he added that there are 100,000 people who say self-care will be the password. 'But I thought I was self-caring,' she said, 'when I pay pension contributions and when I pay social security contributions. Now that we have this debate on supporting structural reforms, it would be very good to pause for a moment and clarify exactly what we mean by these structural reforms, and to ensure that the people, the Citizens of Europe, are involved in this debate of an absolute value system. Thank you very much!

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for this interesting debate and for the support which many of you have clearly expressed for this amendment. For the European Commission this file is of high priority. It will enable us to increase our support in EU Member States and finalise an important package of proposals for deepening economic and monetary union. We are grateful that thanks to your engagement and constructive approach on this legislative text, it looks like the Member States will be able to benefit from a higher budget for technical support and for a more targeted support for those who wish to adopt the euro already next year in 2019. This is a step towards a more integrated, more resilient and more cohesive economic and monetary union and it is a step in the right direction.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Rapporteur. " Mr. Chairman, here, very briefly. Twenty-four Member States have applied and I see no reason why we should not support them, especially for some Member States it means very, very much. We know what problems some Member States have, we also know that we didn't even try to help them, we didn't even try to see what problems they have, so through this support program I think we can rectify that to some extent. I would like to thank once again all those who have engaged in the debate and I would like to thank all those who will vote and support this report. Thank you very much.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, September 11, 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - As the SHADOW EPP rapporteur for this report, I am pleased that it is particularly important that priority should be given to Member States outside the Eurozone, which we want to help achieve convergence as soon as possible and meet the criteria for entry into the Eurozone. This makes this Structural Reform Support Programme part of our European Solidarity, Cohesion and Convergence Plan across the European Union.  The proposal to amend the regulation increases the financial envelope of the Structural Reform Support Programme for 2017-2020 to €222.8 million. The programme was set up to strengthen Member States' capacity to prepare and implement growth-sustaining administrative and structural reforms. Support under the programme is provided by the Commission at the request of a Member State and may cover a variety of areas such as public administration, income management, growth and the business environment, the labour market, education, health and social services and the financial sector. It is important to stress that countries have already submitted requests for reforms and reform projects for over €132 million worth of funding from this Programme, thus addressing the need for additional programme funding.  As for Croatia, the Government has proposed 17 projects and requests for assistance for reform projects with a total value of 2.3 million euros since the start of the programme.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Derek Vaughan, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the impact of EU cohesion policy on Northern Ireland (2017/2225(INI)) (A8-0240/2018).

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, can I first of all thank my colleagues on the Committee on Regional Development (REGI) for their cooperation on this report. It is a good time to have such a report because something important is happening. By that I mean of course the discussions on the next MFF and the negotiations on the next cohesion policy regulations, because unfortunately there are still some people who don’t see the value of cohesion policy. They want to cut the spending and reduce its influence, but I think in Northern Ireland we have an example where cohesion policy has worked. Colleagues will recall that, since the Good Friday Agreement in 1998, Northern Ireland has been on a path of peace and we should remember that along that path they have been helped by the European Union. Northern Ireland has benefited from various cohesion policy programmes: ERDF, ESF, the rural development plan, and also fisheries funding. Unfortunately these are likely to go post—2020. But there are also Interreg, and the PEACE Programme and these can – and should – remain, whatever happens post—2020. Prior to drafting my report, we took a REGI delegation to Northern Ireland. It was a good and interesting delegation. We saw Interreg cross-border projects in Derry—Londonderry, for example health projects where people cross the border to receive health care. We also met and talked to businesses who benefited from cross—border operations. So it brings social and economic benefits. In Belfast we met the Survivor and Victim Support Project and we heard about the excellent work they were doing, and we saw and heard from two community projects funded by the PEACE Programme. Let me remind colleagues that the PEACE Programme in the current round received EUR 270 million. We saw two centres where people – mainly young people – from both communities came together to learn, to dance, to sing, to enjoy themselves, to play sport and to socialise together. I believe that projects like these are vital if we are to continue to break down mistrust, particularly amongst future generations. I think one of the reasons why this type of project has been so successful is because it has used a bottom-up approach, where people from communities have come together and done things together to benefit them as individuals and to benefit their communities. Another thing we learned on our delegation was that EU funds are seen as neutral. That kept coming up time after time. So EU funds are accepted because they don’t come from the UK, they don’t come from the Irish Government, they come from the European Union. As I said, this means all communities have accepted EU funding and have put that funding to good use. That is why one of the key findings of this report is that the PEACE Programme and Interreg must continue post—2020, whatever happens. Another key recommendation in our report is that the PEACE Programme can be used as a model and used elsewhere where there has been conflict and where there has been mistrust. So we are looking to the future here to say that cohesion policy should continue and this would be another good use for it. I believe that this is a good report. There have been lots of discussions in the REGI Committee and it has had good support in the REGI Committee. So please, colleagues, let’s send a message to the European Union, to the Irish Government and, in particular, to the UK Government, that Interreg and, in particular, the PEACE Programme are so important. We must continue to fund them post—2020, whatever happens.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first and foremost, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur Mr Vaughan on his report. I believe it brings an accurate and some much—needed light to the decisive impact that cohesion policy has had in Northern Ireland. I had the pleasure back in November of attending an exhibition hosted by the European Parliament on peace and Interreg (European Territorial Co—operation) projects and I have also had the opportunity over the last four years to meet several beneficiaries, and what I witnessed through their stories was a vivid and concrete expression of what cohesion policy can help us to achieve. As you said, EU investments have helped bring people close together and increased the prosperity of Northern Ireland and its citizens, but most importantly, they have contributed to the economic transformation of a region that was facing many complex challenges. I think it is quite obvious that over the past 20 years, EU funding for Northern Ireland has been both substantial in size and successful in its implementation. This includes bespoke actions and investments from all European structural and investment funds. The ERDF – European Regional Development Fund – alone has provided over EUR 1 billion through regional growth programmes for Northern Ireland. In addition, Northern Ireland and the border region of Ireland benefited from over EUR 2 billion through peace and Interreg funding. Honourable Members, I am particularly pleased to hear from you that the Regional Development Committee’s fact—finding mission to Northern Ireland was enriching and confirmed that the programmes were delivering efficiently on the ground. Whether we are talking about funding the science park in Derry/Londonderry, thus helping small-and medium-sized enterprises and micro businesses to innovate, or about supporting gross community dialogue in Belfast through urban regeneration projects, I think cohesion policy has brought a holistic approach in Northern Ireland which has been instrumental in addressing the multifaceted challenges of the region. As rightly underlined in your report, the peace and Interreg cross-border programmes have been of particular importance, and they are making a vital contribution to long-term partnership, peace and prosperity. I took good note of the report’s call for a continuation of funding for the peace and Interreg programmes after 2020 and my message to you is clear: we are on the same wavelength. You all know and we know that the Commission included in its draft cohesion policy package for the next programming period a proposal for a new peace programme – we call it the ‘peace+ programme’, combining the current peace and Ireland-Northern Ireland cross-border programme. I think this a very tangible sign of the Commission’s continuous commitment and of our firm belief that cross—border funding remains paramount for north—south cooperation in Ireland. Thank you for your attention and I am looking forward to our debate.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I will begin my speech with the concluding words of the rapporteur, who said that this is ‘one good report’. And indeed, I believe it is a good report, and moreover it is a timely report. Before going into detail, I would like to share a few figures with you. Almost two million citizens in Northern Ireland benefited from EUR seven billion in EU funding from 2007 to 2017. And behind these numbers, behind the statistics, there are people’s lives. People’s lives that have been changed because of EU cohesion policy. I believe this is one of the textbook examples of how EU cohesion policy is changing the environment. Moreover, this contribution has been done with cross-financing and coordination with the Peace Programme so, yet again, the European Union has shown that it knows how to work to bring back peace – and peace is priceless. Here, I would like to congratulate Commissioner Crețu, because she dedicated herself to a better-working cohesion policy, and I think that as we approach the end of our mandate, we can show some very good results of what the European Union has achieved with its cohesion policy.

name: John HOWARTH
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Thank you Mr President. I congratulate my friend, the rapporteur, on an excellent and concise report. It is important to remember that the essence of the Good Friday Agreement is that it provides the framework that enables the different traditions in Northern Ireland to coexist peacefully. The important work reviewed in this report aims to maintain the climate in which peace can continue to evolve. Let us not forget that the Good Friday Agreement was approved of overwhelmingly by people on both sides of the Irish border. Sadly, there are some Brexiteers, like Mr Rees Mogg in the UK Parliament, who want to pick and choose which bits of democracy they respect, and they dismiss the importance of maintaining this agreement after Brexit. To dismiss the agreement is to take peace for granted, and when you take peace for granted, you are on a very slippery slope. So it is vital that the work described in this report continues, even if cohesion policy cannot be the vehicle. If and when Brexit goes ahead, there are other financial instruments in the union that can fill the gap, as paragraph 10 of this report makes clear.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, can I first of all congratulate the rapporteur and say that, two decades on from the Belfast Agreement, Northern Ireland has been transformed economically and socially. And there is no doubt that European support has played an important role in terms of economic development and social cohesion.
