In recent years, funding from the European Regional Development Fund has supported a vast range of projects, including investment in the development of tourism as well as infrastructure projects. Many projects have benefited from the European Social Fund, helping individuals and families across Northern Ireland, supporting initiatives which have helped to increase skills and reduce economic inactivity. The Peace Programme has supported several big-ticket projects as well but, in my view, the greatest impact is the role it has played on the ground and in communities. So I welcome the fact that the report recognises the important contribution these funds have made to Northern Ireland and I very much agree with the rapporteur and his comments on the bottom-up approach. Can I also say that, since the referendum result, my party has been very clear: we do not want support of this kind to be disrupted or diminished as a result of Brexit. However, I have to say I am more than disappointed by the report’s suggestion that without these funds the peace process would be put at risk. To me, this is overly simplistic at best, and at worst it risks giving a potential excuse to those who seek to justify terrorism. I have to ask a question here, maybe to the rapporteur and maybe to the Commissioner. If we decide, or if it is decided, to give funds to Northern Ireland after 2020, and the United Kingdom is no longer part of the European Union and there will be no MEPs from Northern Ireland within the Chamber, who is actually going to represent Northern Ireland? The UK will not be at the Council table, there will be no Commissioner from the United Kingdom, and there will be no MEPs in this House, so that is a very difficult road to go down. It is an interesting road that needs to be addressed, and it is one I have certainly given some thought to, so it will be very interesting to see how the Commission and the Council actually deal with that problem. However, I congratulate the rapporteur and I thank all those involved very much.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr. Chairman, here, I could respond immediately to Mr. Nicholson, and that is if anything, let's keep the Interreg programme known in a way that finances those cross-border projects of member states and non-member states. The United Kingdom and Northern Ireland will not be part of the European Union, but the Interreg programme exists and it can fund everything we have seen in Northern Ireland. And what we saw was impressive. Indeed, I was delighted with what we saw, the money that came from the European Union created peace. The reconciliation continues, it is evident that communities want it, they really live together in some way, precisely thanks to what came from the Good Friday reconciliation and the Good Friday Agreement, but also thanks to the financial resources of the European Union. Peace program must continue, but peace program must be expanded. Let's extend it to those countries where there were conflicts, and that's my Croatia, that's Kosovo, that's Bosnia and Herzegovina, that's Macedonia. We have reason to expand the peace programme, it proved successful in Northern Ireland, we had a conflict there, we had it in the Balkans. Let's expand it because we think we have great results and we need to take advantage of that.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Thank you, Mr President. ‘I have been living here my whole life. I don’t want to go back to how things were before. I cannot do that. I cannot live in this neighbourhood if we go back to how it used to be.’ This was the very simple message from a woman from a heavily segregated area in Belfast whose neighbourhood and community had benefited from peace funds, where a big community centre had been built, and slowly but surely things started to change, things started to develop. She told us about her experiences, about her life, about the history of the place where she grew up. She told us about the violence, the division, the economic devastation. She didn’t have any political agenda. She probably didn’t even have a strong opinion about the European Union. All that she wanted us to know was her story and for her story to be taken into consideration when we take decisions here in the European Parliament. When we went to Northern Ireland, with a delegation from this Parliament, no matter where we went, no matter whom we talked to, the message was always very similar. The peace funding has played an integral role to build peace in a conflict-ridden area in Europe, not only to rebuild infrastructure and the economy, but also to bring people together who had been segregated and separated for decades. Peace is very hard to build and very easy to destroy. As Europeans we have learnt this lesson over and over again in the past centuries. Now for me, it is very clear, we have to make sure that the peace funding will not be lost. We cannot let this Brexit disaster mess up the peace in Northern Ireland. As Europeans we have a responsibility, a responsibility to protect a hard-earned peace.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I commend Derek Vaughan on his report. Cohesion funding has played a huge role in supporting the Good Friday Agreement via aiding thousands and thousands of people who depend on this funding for their businesses, community projects and infrastructure. The British Government says it will guarantee EU funding streams to the north post-2020. However, what if there is no Brexit deal? The civil servants in the north have already identified a shortfall of over 10 million. Even if the British were to deliver on their dodgy guarantees, the British Cabinet – a gang of incompetent fools – say people should keep calm and carry on and ignore the Brexit chaos. MEPs, especially the two unionists from the north of Ireland, need to endorse this report and to vote in favour of it. No washed-out kingdom fixated on its empire of old will ever serve the interests of the people of Ireland, north and south. The north of Ireland needs a differentiated approach. It needs all strands of cohesion funding to apply to it, not just now, but in the post-Brexit future, and as the only MEP from the north who’s fighting Brexit every day, I deeply appreciate the fact that the north is getting this kind of special financial assistance and financial special status post-Brexit.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Thank you Mr President, and thank you to our colleague Mr Vaughan and indeed the whole Regional Development Committee (REGI) for this report. Cohesion funds have played a part in consolidating progress in Northern Ireland. This has not been without faults. In respect of innocent victims of terrorism, I would question the reports premise that this has always been viewed as neutral money in how it has been allocated. And in more recent times, community organisations including voluntary and womenʼs organisations have argued that red tape has curtailed benefits for local people. Of course, it is money that also originates from UK taxpayers as an EU Member State and so our focus going forward must not be on how it is lost, but on how it can be used to bring even better benefits. The Government has indicated that there will be a shared prosperity fund across the UK post-Brexit. It also wants to agree cooperation accords with the EU to collaborate in specific areas of investment. Moving forward, we will continue to work with our government to ensure that the commitments towards peace and Interreg programmes are honoured. This is necessary and positive work, and we look forward to working in goodwill and cooperation.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: – Mr President, this is a special report. It is an implementation report that was initiated by Parliament and we produced it at the right moment. We have heard what the implementation will entail: it is very positive and, in this regard, if you look to the future it is extremely important to note that we already have instruments under the Interreg programme going cross-border and working in a very targeted and dedicated way. We could see, especially during our visit, that this works. Let me say that borders are, in fact, something from the past. We resolved this issue: we waved away the ‘old scars’ both politically and also in a practical sense. My wish and the wish of the EPP Group is that Mr Barnier – who, I know, already has the Peace+ programme in his toolbox – also resolves it and that people will again feel the contribution of Europe in the future. This is worth talking about. Good report, Mr Vaughan!

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. I had the honour of chairing the delegation of the Committee on Regional Development in Northern Ireland in March this year. The 1998 Good Friday Agreement was on the verge of its twentieth anniversary. We have had many interlocutors from politics and civil society, and I was particularly touched by two things: firstly, that all the interlocutors praised the EU aid to date as necessary and effective in order to put an end to the previously violent conflicts between the social groups in Northern Ireland, but secondly, that everyone assured us that the peace and reconciliation process in Northern Ireland is not yet sustainable enough and is still fragile. A hard Brexit without the continuation of EU programmes in and with Northern Ireland will break the old conflicts. That is the message they gave us, and we should take this warning very seriously, as we saw not so long ago in Derry. Those who play their political Brexit games on the backs of the people and the fates of Northern Ireland, in particular, should heed this.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I, too, would like to thank My colleague Vaughan for the report that has come at a very good time and is, in my opinion, of very good quality. The importance of European funds is particularly evident in the cross-border cooperation and for these cross-border programmes. Cohesion policy is designed to eliminate certain disadvantages, I think it is also intended to heal old wounds, not to revive new conflicts, and to make up for communities. In Northern Ireland, we have seen real change in both the economy and social cohesion, and I think that change has been positive and it would be good not to lose that result.  I was very happy to hear from the Commissioner that it is the PEACE+ programme in the new programming period that should include the border areas directly, which I think is very good. After all, the Commissioner has done a great lot, I would like to commend her in this area, and there should be a place for those cross-border funds in the new programming period, because it is these programmes that are supposed to show us how cross-border cooperation can be built, and I think this is particularly important for the Balkans.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my full support for the continuity in Northern Ireland of cohesion programmes and especially the PEACE programme, which is fundamental to the consolidation of the peace process outside the Good Friday Agreement. Peace is an example of how the Union, with political and financial commitment, has contributed on European soil to resolving a conflict by reconciling communities and promoting fairer development. That is why Brexit must not prevent this exemplary support for peace and social justice from being maintained from the European Union.  This intervention is also a model for other European regions that have experienced serious episodes of violence , such as the Basque Country – because, although the origin and development of ETA's Irish conflict and terrorism are not comparable, some of its consequences are. Taking advantage of the experiences promoted by the European Union and the recognition derived from them is very useful for solving problems of coexistence and values on which the Basques want to continue working well accompanied.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, ideologically imposed austerity and an ineffective devolution deal from Westminster have left Northern Ireland less economically developed than other regions of the UK for decades. The government’s own impact assessments predict a devastating 8% hit to the economic growth of Northern Ireland if the UK leaves the European Union, and others have put the figure far higher. Two years on from the EU referendum, the government are yet to lay out a single workable plan to maintain the integrity of the Good Friday Agreement, one of the EU’s most celebrated symbols of peace. Theresa May’s customs plans have unravelled. They are bureaucratic, unworkable and designed to paper over the cracks of a divided Tory Government, rather than deliver a deal that works for the British people. The Conservatives’ dirty deal with the DUP and the collapse of power sharing in Stormont, with no imminent sign of its return, further add to the lack of Northern Ireland’s democratic voice during the negotiating process. So it is time for all of us to acknowledge that there is only one way to maintain the full integrity of the Irish border and prevent the economic and social downturn that Brexit will inevitably bring, and that is to stop it. That’s what the majority of the people in Northern Ireland want.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It welcomes a common rather consistent opinion on the reasonableness of the funds spent to improve the situation in Northern Ireland. I must say that I welcome this, but what is worrying is this next perspective, which has emerged in recent voices in this debate in this debate, which is, of course, linked to Brexit.  Brexit for Northern Ireland is a serious threat. It is worth taking this opportunity, paying attention to what we have achieved so far, to try to apply a specific recipe for the approaching perspective. Apart from the UK, Northern Ireland may be the first major negative beneficiary of the lack of relevant agreements and prescriptions for the next perspective, and I note this shortcoming.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, in the light of all your interventions, it seems we all agree that there is strong consensus about the fact that cohesion policy programmes have been of key importance for the economic and social progress of Northern Ireland. This also means that the implementation of programmes has been successful overall. In particular, the Peace and Interreg (European Territorial Cooperation) projects have demonstrated that cross-border cooperation is not an abstract concept: it is part of the daily life of citizens and it provides a space for people to come together and forge new partnerships. I liked very much what you said – that peace is very easy to destroy, but very hard to build, and we should not take it for granted. I thank you very much for all your interventions. We will have the opportunity later today during the debate on Mr Hetman’s report to discuss further the importance of ensuring strong cohesion in border regions, but we have here a first taste with Northern Ireland. It is undoubtedly one of the most telling examples of what cohesion policy has helped to achieve in border regions and beyond. There are countless examples where European funding has made a real difference to citizens, businesses, researchers, schools and local and regional authorities, and this report recognises that cohesion policy is one of the keys that can unlock our social, economic and cultural transformation. We must strive to defend it, and make every effort to further increase its effectiveness. This is why, as I said, the Commission has proposed a balanced budget beyond 2020 which preserves cohesion policy as a policy which is both strong and for all the regions.  I trust that the findings in your report will underpin your reflection on the future of cohesion policy and that you will give the negotiation of the legislative packages the highest priority so that a new legislative framework can be adopted a soon as possible. This is together with the negotiation of the MFF. We will also respond to the question from Mr Nicholson on how this peace+ programme will be implemented in the future. Let’s see how the Brexit negotiations turn out. Thank you once again for all your contributions.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I’ll just try to respond to a couple of points and then make a few concluding remarks. First of all, I would like to thank colleagues for their positive comments right across the Chamber, although I think one or two colleagues didn’t quite get the e—mail about what this report is supposed to be about and what it is not supposed to be about. But I think, in general, the comments were very, very welcome. I particularly welcome the comments from Mr Nicholson and the question he raised, and I think you, Commissioner, partly answered that. We need to look at what Member States – and particularly, maybe, the Irish Government – are saying about how EU funds are administered in the future and how Northern Ireland is represented in those discussions. I also welcomed his comments when he said that Northern Ireland has come a long way. There has been huge economic improvement and tensions have been reduced, but we do know that those tensions still bubble away. When we were there on the delegations, one of the things we were told was that some survey work had been done and since the referendum, attitudes have hardened amongst the community. So I hope nobody gets the impression – and they should not get the view from the report – that no EU funds means a return to troubles. The report isn’t saying that, and I wouldn’t say that, but what I am saying – and what I think the report says – is that the EU funds have made a valuable contribution to reducing those tensions and conflicts. So I think that is the important point in terms of Mr Nicholson’s view. Therefore EU funds should continue in the future. We should continue to fund Interreg and the PEACE Programme. We have seen for ourselves on our delegation how welcome those funds are and how important those funds are for making a contribution to communities. Whatever happens in the future – deal or no deal, as Ms Anderson said – the UK Government, the Irish Government and the European Union should commit to continuing to operate and fund Interreg and the PEACE Programme. Ms Dodds is right that nothing is ever important. In the REGI Committee we spend a huge amount of time talking about bureaucracy and simplifying things so we all want to reduce bureaucracy and we also want to make things as simple as possible, particularly for users. But, overall, these funds have been good. They have delivered on the ground. As I said in my earlier contribution, one of the reasons why they have delivered on the ground is because local people themselves have owned it. They have decided how they want to spend the money. They have decided how they are going to spend the money on important things, which are going to impact on their communities. So, just to conclude, I think it is absolutely vital that these funds continue in the future. I hope everybody in this Parliament, right across the political divide, right across the Chamber, would support this report tomorrow and send a clear message from this Parliament.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, September 11, 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Written. – It is clear that the extensive european cohesion policy programmes have paid off in Northern Ireland over the last decade. The European contribution of more than EUR 1 billion between 2014 and 2020 through various funds means, among other things, : Continued economic growth with the lowest unemployment rates in ten years;  Intensive guidance on the transformation of heavy industry into a more service-oriented economy;  Sustainable economic activities.  In addition, the EU plays a fundamental role in the peace talks between Ireland and Northern Ireland. Regardless of the outcome of the Brexit negotiations, I believe that European support for Northern Ireland must remain assured. Northern Ireland has been taking part in the ambitious European project for a considerable period of time, and intensive cooperation – certainly on peace projects – must therefore be continued in my opinion.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Pascal Arimont, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the implementation of specific measures for Greece under Regulation (EU) 2015/1839 (2018/2038(INI)) (A8-0244/2018).

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We all remember 2015, which was particularly painful for our Greek friends. Indeed, in the context of Greece's severe financial and economic crisis, the country was no longer able to guarantee and guarantee the necessary co-financing for the Structural Funds projects. There were simply no public funds. In concrete terms, this meant that many very important infrastructure projects in Greece, which had already begun, were about to end, and even worse: if these projects had not been completed in the 2007-2013 funding period, Greece would have had to repay significant funds to the EU. So we were faced with an absolute worst-case scenario. The situation threatened to get even worse if these payments had to be made to the EU.  It was therefore important to act very quickly, very wisely and very purposefully. The EU Commission then proposed an amendment to the general regulation of the Structural Funds: in order to allow the country to use the available funds, the EU waived the otherwise binding national co-financing share during the last funding period. This has allowed Greece to revert to investment funds that would otherwise have simply fallen into disrepair, as described above. In addition, Greece was granted an advance for the new funding period of EUR 1 billion, which has added up to an aid measure totalling around EUR 2 billion, a sum which this Parliament had to monitor in detail. As special rapporteur, I was responsible for this monitoring on behalf of Parliament and on several occasions on the ground, including in Greece, to talk to the important people there about these projects.  In this context, we in Parliament have repeatedly stressed that these aids cannot be a blank cheque. They should be tied to the implementation and completion of these important projects, including in the context of the structural reforms that Greece had to implement. That is precisely what we wanted to ensure with the report before us today. We have therefore carried out a thorough check that the EU's financial resources, this EUR 2 billion, are being used and used wisely. And what is the result? The result is that Greece has delivered. The country has drawn up and completed a list of priorities for the important projects. These could therefore be terminated on time without any deterioration in resources. Not only that, however, but this report also shows the impact that regional policy can have on regions and countries. We have seen that regional policy projects have helped to make the country grow appreciably economically, to combat high unemployment and to create prospects for people. This was a real success for Greece.  At a time of massive crisis, Structural Funds sometimes accounted for more than half of total public investment. It is estimated that this additional investment in Greece's gross domestic product in 2015 could be slightly more than two percent higher than without these funds. 131 priority projects have been completed over the whole period through these aid measures. These are clearly measurable figures. Such figures should therefore give the critics of regional policy food for thought. Regional policy has created very concrete added value here. This includes real success stories, and I would just remind you of the transport infrastructure that has been created and of important investments in the environment and tourism.  Colleagues, the Greek people have been able to be effectively helped by these special measures. Yes, these aid measures were a sign of lived solidarity. We agreed by a large majority in committee that this was and is an advertisement for the European idea and for regional policy. In the future, care must be taken to ensure that investments remain sustainable, that jobs remain secure and that the quality of life is improved.  In summary, I am convinced that the EU's decision to grant this special aid to Greece was the right decision. It is quite clear what would have happened if we had not done so.  But it also remains clear that this aid measure is and remains a special case. We must all ensure that this will not happen again, either for Greece or for any other Member State. Many thanks to the European Commission, but also to all the Members of this House who have been involved in this report with me. have cooperated and adopted these conclusions. Thank you very much!

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, allow me to start by expressing the Commission’s and my personal condolences to the families and friends of the victims of the devastating fire that hit Greece this summer. I want to assure you that the Commission stands by the Greek people and the public authorities and will explore all possible means of assistance in a spirit of solidarity. I understand that you voted earlier to discuss these issues separately, so we will have this opportunity later. Honourable Members, I would like to congratulate Mr Arimont on this important report. Actually, the specific measures for Greece adopted in October 2015 which we are discussing today were already a vivid expression of this spirit of solidarity, which is the DNA of cohesion policy. I would like to thank the European Parliament and, in particular, the Regional Development Committee, its chair, Ms Mihaylova, and the vice-chair, Mr Arimont, for their continued support in promoting these measures. These measures provided crucial liquidity for Greece. A total amount of approximately EUR 2 billion was paid to the country in 2015 and 2016. This includes around EUR 1 billion of additional pre—financing for the 2014-2020 programmes. Another EUR 1 billion paid as a consequence of the increase of the co-financing rate to 100% and the removal of the 95% ceiling for the total advance and interim payments for the 2007-2013 programming period. In times of severe liquidity problems, these measures also alleviated the burden on the national budget. They reduced by approximately EUR 1 billion the amounts needed in national co-financing for 2007-2013. Thanks to the additional liquidity and to the fact that it was put on a special ring-fenced account, Greece was able to restart its payments to beneficiaries of co-financing projects who, in turn, resumed work on this project, thereby initiating new expenditure which could then be reimbursed by the Commission. I note with great satisfaction that Greece managed to complete the important project in the programming period 2007-2013 in the fields of transport, digital infrastructure, entrepreneurship, the environment and social and health care. The completion of this project has triggered the virtuous circle of job creation, economic activity and growth. One of the most obvious examples is the five motorway concessions, part of the main TEN-T (Trans-European Transport Networks) network. By mid-2015, works had stopped and there was a very serious risk that they would not be resumed because of the lack of funds. The liquidity provided through the specific measures has been instrumental to ensuring that in the course of 2017, all five projects were completed. I actually had the pleasure of taking part in the inauguration event for the Tempe Valley tunnel on the Aegean motorway. All the way through the support from the European Parliament was essential, so I would like, once again, to thank you for your contribution, with particular acknowledgement to the honourable Member Arimont for having sponsored these measures and for his thorough report. Thank you for your attention. I am looking forward to your comments.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, today we are closing here an effort launched in October 2015 by the Committee on Regional Development, giving an important exception to my country, Greece, by Regulation (EU) 2015/1839. It is an important initiative, as the European Union has shown its solidarity with Greece at a very critical point. It is important because Greece lost 26% of GDP during the crisis and its unemployment soared. It is important because, in May 2018, Greece still has unemployment of 19.5% according to Eurostat and youth unemployment for 2017 was 43.7%. With the exception of Greece, Greece received a total amount of EUR 20.4 billion from cohesion policy funding for the period 2007-2013. It was, as you said, Commissioner, a very important injection of liquidity at a time when political uncertainty was in danger of blowing up any attempt to absorb Community funds. I would like to say here, ladies and gentlemen, a big thank you to all of you. The European Union acted immediately and acted effectively. Cohesion policy has proved to be the cornerstone of European solidarity. In the new era when we need to combine financial instruments, we should not deprive cohesion resources but give impetus to projects with added value. The partners, the friends, seem to be in the difficult and solidarity has been given to Greece in practice. You stood in Greece when we were on the brink. It remains for all Europeans to learn from the truly tragic situation my country has experienced and to say together that we will never repeat it again.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: On behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D). As Mr De Clercq has already pointed out, it is not a good opportunity to make a more Arimont, the aid measures to Greece have been very important and have enabled it to implement a development programme well. From a political point of view, we have made it very clear as a group that this mechanism, however extraordinary, has in fact served to breathe new life into an economy that had been asphyxiated by equally extraordinary austerity measures, pointing out that the causes of the crisis were very complex and the effects on the Greek social and economic fabric were very serious. In short, it seemed clear to us that the positive effect of the increased use of the Structural Funds, thanks to European funds, has become apparent, especially from a long-term perspective and in relation to the continuing questioning of the value of the results of the Structural Funds. In this sense, precisely because of the extraordinary nature of the intervention, and also because of the contribution it can make to better understanding the impact of these policies on citizens, I believe that it is important to continue to support the topicality of cohesion policy in the face of its detractors.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the memoranda have led my country, Greece, to an absolute economic disaster, they have led to a social cemetery with a huge number of unemployed, in poverty, with a reduction in GDP to 26%. At the same time, the Memorandums imposed a reduction in the Public Investment Programme, i.e. a reduction in the amounts to be invested: in fact Greece could not finance the European programmes that needed co-financing because the troika said at the time that the deficit would increase. This huge problem has been highlighted here since 2014 and fortunately there have been these arrangements, fortunately there has been this exception that has enabled these EUR 2 billion funds to flow. Special arrangements are needed. It takes a special relationship between Greece and the European Union, with many exceptions to the implementation of the Treaty, in order for the country to be able to breathe, to move forward, because it cannot compete with the other economies of the European Union in a damaged Greek economy. That is why we, as "GREECE-THE OTHER ROAD", propose a special relationship between Greece within the European Union and within the euro area.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, three years ago I had the honour of being rapporteur for the legislative report on specific measures for Greece related to support from the Structural Investment Funds on behalf of this Parliament's Committee on Regional Development. Today we monitor the implementation of the specific measures under Regulation (EU) 2015/1839, designed to provide Greece with support at a crucial time of liquidity shortages and lack of public investment. This is beautifully reflected in colleague Arimont's report.  I would like to emphasise here the important role of cohesion policy as the Union's main investment instrument for strengthening competitiveness, economic growth and reducing inequalities, given that the ESI Funds represent the largest source of direct investment in Greece. The REPORT of the REGI Committee invariably underlines that the Structural Funds have a significant positive impact on gross domestic product and social, economic and territorial cohesion in general.  I take this case to welcome the fact that, thanks to the European Union funds under this Regulation, the number of projects declared as incomplete has significantly decreased and the absorption of the Structural Funds has significantly improved, with Greece being the first Member State to fully absorb the available resources and reaching a 100% absorption rate for the previous period. In addition, as of March 2018, Greece showed a 28% implementation rate for the current programming period, leading it among the best performing Member States overall. Cohesion Policy has therefore fulfilled its role through these specific measures. At the same time, I would like to stress the importance of structural reforms and I expect Greece to continue to make full use of the opportunities provided by the Structural Reform Support Programme with a view to creating and strengthening an appropriate investment environment.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, in recent months the Greek Government has successfully implemented the so—called specific measures for Greece, an investment package that has been adopted in view of the severe economic and financial crisis that not only – but especially – hit Greece. Many of the measures coming from the European level, namely austerity, have actually not helped the situation in recent years. Quite the contrary, the specific measures for Greece have shown that European policy can help and alleviate the crisis. This is exactly what cohesion policy, and the European Union as a whole, should be about: solidarity. We congratulate the Greek Government, which has made the best use of specific measures offered by the European Union to help Greece out of the crisis. This way the net financial impact of the specific measures amounted to EUR 1.5 billion. The specific measures have thus been a success and extremely helpful. Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur, as well as all the shadow rapporteurs, for the very constructive and useful cooperation on this report.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Greece is a total disaster.  Between 2008 and 2016, gross domestic production was almost halved from 360 billion euros to 192 billion euros. 40% of young people are now unemployed, and much more if we took into account all those who leave. And yet, as I understand it, we have given this country, or we have helped it, for almost EUR 500 billion. Let me explain: 100 billion by the cancellation of private debts, 100 billion by carrying over the various debts, or 200 billion donations; and $300 billion by the total repurchase of all debt. And all this for a result of halving and economically destroying this country. Even a mad king, completely insane, would not have been able to carry out such a policy. And yet that was our policy.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, I will go against what my colleague said earlier. I must acknowledge to the author of this report that he admits that the consistently negative growth rates of recent years have failed to cope with the three memoranda imposed on Greece by the lenders. Usually, from previous governments, the current government and institutions, we hear the exact opposite. On the other hand, statistics are the easiest way to lie. Eurostat tells us that unemployment in Greece has fallen to around 20%. What it does not tell us is that new jobs are usually part-time and with much lower wages than those that existed before. Of course, it is unrealistic to expect growth to accelerate when wages have fallen to current levels and when, as a result, the purchasing power of the Greeks has been annihilated. Indeed, the amounts given for public investment in Greece were significant. But most of these sums did not remain in the country but ended up in the large construction companies, many of which are based in the so-called large countries of Europe. It would have been much more beneficial for the Greeks if they had been given money that would have ended up in the real economy and helped to create an economic environment that would favour growth.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: – Mr President, thank you very much for the opportunity to look back to the moment in 2015 when we were convinced that those projects which were planned and that could not be co-financed, could be fixed in Greece. We did it. And the last two speakers... well I don’t know where they were talking about. This was a specific measure, and there was a deep debate here in the Parliament in the Economic Affairs Committee. They asked ‘who is following it?’ and we said ‘we will appoint a standing rapporteur’. He is now sitting: Mr Arimont. And he did his job, two years later, three years later to see what comes out. And the conclusion is clear: the work was fixed, the work was done. Good results and even with more capacity to perform in the future. So I was convinced and I am convinced that this is a good measure. Special times, special situation, special measures. We did it.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the European Structural and Investment Funds are key tools of the European Union for directly and indirectly enhancing the profitability of business groups. This is what the report itself admits, stating that '63% of all payments (...) it concerned aid for enterprises and business projects directly contributing to the profitability of enterprises and the reduction of so-called risk", while the remaining 37% 'concerned State aid actions for infrastructure projects' which the large groups again need to facilitate their action and profitability. After all, in the years of record-breaking absorption boasted by the SYRIZA-ANEL government and the European Union, the anti-labour offensive took off and saw the greatest losses in wages, pensions and labour rights. The JRC supports the demands of the labour movement which requires that all these funds, which in any case come from the harsh taxation of workers, be used to finance projects vital to the relief and satisfaction of modern popular needs.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking my colleague Arimont for not only this report, but also for the work he has done as our rapporteur for Greece. I really appreciate his work. I have to ask: what does it actually mean if you give someone a 100% contribution? I think that this is indeed an expression of the highest cohesion, some solidarity and belonging that we have shown with the Greek people. It is actually a full payment and there is no doubt, as my colleague Spyraki also pointed out, that this money has helped to grow the Greek economy, that is absolutely indisputable, we are seeing these results today. And if you can't see them, I think he's blind. Employment: the money has helped to develop infrastructure, to help specific businesses. I think this was an example of effective aid, which – I do not know to what extent – was and can be repeatable, but I think it was an expression of genuine European belonging.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr President, I would like to say that Regulation (EU) 2015/1839 has achieved one hundred per cent. The representatives of all the political groups admit this with the sad exception of the extreme right, which wants europe to be dissolved and does not believe in cohesion policies. The figures prove success and the unanimity of the European Parliament proves success. Not a single euro was charged to the European taxpayer, but with this additional liquidity, my country Greece has a one hundred per cent absorption into the programme of the previous period. Not a single euro has been lost, it is the first to be absorbed in the present period and while, in July 2015, we were discussing Greece's Grexit from the euro, we are now discussing Greece's Grexit from the memoranda. This is a success story not only for my country but also for the Commission and for the European Parliament.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, in this day and age, even the most uninformed of what is happening in Europe does not find it difficult to realise that Greece's wealth of all kinds has been plundered and committed for at least a hundred more years in order to save the euro and European banks. This, of course, also escapes the attention of the colleague who has already left and some of those present here who want to distort things. It is a fact that Greece has been given some money. But if one thinks about the usury loans with which this money was given and the fact that this money went either to banks, to construction companies, or to other entrepreneurs to profiteer and impoverished the Greek worker, creating working conditions in the Middle Ages, then he can say that they are able to say what they say because they obviously live in another parallel world. With the usury loans given by the lenders in Greece they have impoverished the Greek people and taken away from them all right to hope. So the European Union owes Greece a great deal, and that is exactly what we are asking for and not the crumbs of the 22 billion that are currently being discussed that will be given to my country.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The Representative of the Commission was kind enough to say in great detail how grateful he must be, right, greece, for the many gifts it has received from the European Union. But he forgot a gift, and that is the mass migration that Greece has received from the European Union and Mrs Merkel. The footage you see online of greeks suffering is shocking.  The Commission representative says that tourism has been boosted and services supported. yes, but what happened? How much damage has migration caused to tourism on the islands and so on? Have services been able to quantify the damage caused by migration to the Greeks and how the balance sheet is now? Thank you very much!

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the House for this opportunity to look back. And, looking back at what we decided together three years ago, I think we can see there is overall unanimity on the fact that the revision of the Common Provisions Regulation and the measures specific to Greece have achieved their goal. They have allowed Greece to address a severe liquidity problem that had occurred at that time, to inject cash and to relaunch investments in the real economy – and all this in a relatively short period of time. As a matter of fact, Greece was the first state to reach a 100% absorption rate of available funds under the 2007—2013 programming period and it is also among the best-performing Member States in terms of implementation in the 2014—2020 programming period. The good progress so far should be the driver for Greece to continue, and increase even further, efforts to put in place a solid pipeline of new mature projects, which could generate expenditure and ensure a good performance in the years to come. The Commission has been providing – and will continue to provide – hands—on technical support to the Greek authorities in facilitating the management and implementation of the funds. More generally, I think the specific measures in favour of Greece embody the very essence of cohesion policy, namely championing solidarity between Member States so that regions can grow together, supporting growth enhancing investments to boost the economy. This is exactly what the Commission has tried to reinforce in its post—2020 proposal for cohesion policy by securing a policy for all regions and by making sure that resources are efficiently channelled to where they are the most needed. On the other issue that was raised, I can assure you that we are standing by the Greek people and the Greek authorities – as well as the Italians – and we are working together to integrate the migrants. That is another issue and I am at your disposal if you would like to talk about it separately, but it is not the subject of this debate.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I shall be very brief. I have two minutes, but I will not use them. I am not going to comment on the comments of the extreme left and the far right, because I do not share their view at all. Moreover, their comments were not about the special measures or about regional policy, so I do not have to comment on that. Nevertheless, I would like to summarise what is important: there was a special situation. We have responded to this with a special measure, and with great success, with great measurable success. I would therefore like to thank all those who have helped to make this a reality. We have not palaverted for Greece in these difficult times, we have not criticised for the sake of criticism, we have acted. That was right and important. And that is why I would like to thank all those who have contributed to this: thank you very much!

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, September 11, 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Written. – The jubilant mood on the situation in Greece continues. The last aid package has been provided, the country can borrow again on the capital market and unemployment is falling. Of course, cohesion policy, which we are talking about today, has contributed to this positive note. In this sense, I agree with the measures taken by Europe to combat unemployment, for example. However, we are not there yet. We must not abandon the Greek people. After all, youth unemployment is sky-high at 42 percent. Greek debt, at 180% of GDP, is even the highest in Europe. A debt that, through accounting tricks, will hang around the necks of the Greek people for years to go.  That is why I conclude that there is a great deal of suffering behind the figures. And not just in Greece. That is why, as EMPL rapporteur of the proposed common provisions, I propose to increase eu project pre-financing. The less developed regions must also receive more EU funds in order to make real work on social policy. Only in this way can we continue to build a social Europe in the future.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the fires that broke out in July 2018 in Mati, in the Attica region of Greece, and the EU response (2018/2847(SDR)).

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the Commission I would like to express once more my condolences to the families and loved ones of the victims of the recent forest fires in Greece. I would like also to pay tribute to the courage and the outstanding work of the brave firefighters who fought the blaze. Commissioner Stylianides flew to Greece in the hours following the tragedy and helped in coordinating the EU response. The Union’s Civil Protection Mechanism reacted immediately to Greece’s request for assistance. Capacities were mobilised and deployed quickly in the affected areas. The response was substantial: first, ground forest-firefighting modules and vehicles from Cyprus; second, Canadair firefighting planes from Italy and Spain and two planes from Romania were deployed; and nine Member States in total made offers. Helping countries that face forest fires was a top priority this summer for the European Union and it remains a top priority. The Commission’s Emergency Response Coordination Centre is working 24 hours a day and is in constant contact with national authorities. We stand ready to help Greece further whenever needed. With regard to the wildfires in Attica, as Commissioner for Regional Policy I was in direct contact with the Greek authorities from the moment we knew about the fires. I informed the Greek authorities that the Commission was ready to act swiftly to release the first payment as soon as possible. In addition, I highlighted the possibility, should the conditions for assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund be met, for Greece to benefit from 95% EU co-financing towards reconstruction work supported by cohesion policy. Lastly, I expressed my readiness, after the request from the Greek authorities, to modify Greek cohesion policy programmes to redirect money towards the regeneration of economic activity in the affected areas.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Let me say that, in the face of this immense tragedy, I can only join in president Tajani's condolences and solidarity with the Greek people at the beginning of this sitting.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, at the beginning of today's sitting we observed a minute's silence for the victims in the Eye. What happened there is not described. People burned alive. An entire area has been destroyed. Small and medium-sized enterprises no longer exist. The houses turned to ashes. The infrastructure's gone. It is therefore necessary today to act immediately and immediate action is proof of solidarity. For this reason, I call on you to proceed immediately and flexibly with the movement of funds from the European Solidarity Fund. It is necessary to confirm here today that all available financial instruments from cohesion are at the disposal of the Region and the Greek Government in order to move very quickly to deal with the consequences in this region. The area needs to be rebuilt and re-inhabited. The Eye must be resurrected, relived with the help of the European Union. We therefore call on the European Commission to show practical solidarity with Greece, as was the case with Italy in the recent devastating earthquakes in 2016 and 2017. Greece, as you know, is a country that has suffered, for many consecutive years, a fall in gross domestic product to a total of 25%. It is therefore necessary that it should also be treated exceptionally in this case. Finally, we call on the Commission to allow the immediate reorientation of funds so that the European Structural Fund and the Investment Fund can deal with the enormous problems, the wounds opened by the fire. The New Democracy MEPs have already tabled a resolution on my initiative in the European People's Party.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: On behalf of the S&D Group . The specific actions we are asking the Commission for in the unprecedented tragedy have been described to you by Mrs Spyrakis. I'll look at it from another side. Ninety-eight people died in July and this was because forty-two public structures had a duty, through a tangle of tangled powers, to ensure that they did not burn. And yet, they burned. The current Greek government has not constructed this model of administration. That's why they took care of so many previous ones. He chose the wrong criteria for the chief. He made an almost offensive attempt at communication management, but the bottom line is elsewhere. Forty-two structures, by the way, were trying to provide nine firefighting services without anyone being responsible. This is the case not only in fires but also in the economy that suffers from customer circuits, in the fight against corruption, in development. We therefore ask the Greek government to make an explicit commitment that, out of the 23,143 responsibilities of the Greek services and structures, they will give 30% within a few months to unique managers. Anything less is not acceptable. It will at the same time be a practical apology, though belated, to the relatives of the victims as the government will finally take responsibility for this disaster not happening again.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, we extend our deepest condolences to the relatives of the victims, in whose memory we observed a minute's silence a moment ago. I believe that our insistence and our constant insistence since last Tuesday that this debate should take place here has been vindicated because we owe it to the memory of our dead. I thank the House for accepting our proposal. The deadly fires in Mati highlighted the enormous timeless responsibilities of the Greek State and, at the same time, the inadequacies and incompetence of the Tsipras government. Inadequacy and incompetence that led 98 of our fellow citizens to the fiery death, over 200 injured in hospitals and thousands of homes and businesses in the disaster. No self-criticism from the government so far, when, even yesterday, at the Thessaloniki International Fair, the Prime Minister had the opportunity to say "sorry". And yet, since July 2017 we have called on the government to use the new natural disasters regulation that allows 5% of the European Regional Development Fund to be used for flood defence projects, for fire protection, for reforestation. The Government was deaf to our comments and also to the comments of Mrs Cređu who, on 29 November 2017, in parliament's plenary session in Brussels, asked the government to replace its strategy for dealing with natural disasters and pointed out that there were EUR 1.3 billion available to Greece to deal with these problems. This is where the enormous political responsibilities of the Tsipras government lie, and yet, instead of the Prime Minister sending the minister responsible for handling the NSRF, he upgraded him, made him interior minister. So a message must be given, the government must change policy, it must take advantage of all the opportunities that exist with the Structural Funds, it must take advantage of a new design because, in the end, the Prime Minister suddenly found EUR 500 million and set up a new Agency. Here is the failure of the government and we call on the Commission to contribute to the use of these funds and, of course, to the use of the Solidarity Fund funds.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, on behalf of the entire Greek people, apart from parties and factions, I would like to thank the European Parliament for the solidarity, for a minute of silence, the Commission for what it has done and for what it has told us, and Commissioner Cređu and Commissioner Stylianides and President Juncker. Human pain is great. Ninety-eight dead. No matter what we say now, no matter what we do, the dead don't come back. But the last thing we have to do, because we don't deserve it, is to let cynical games of petty political confrontation and caving in. What are we supposed to do? Strengthen civil protection, both at national level – and much needs to change in the country from Greece – and at European level, creating a strong umbrella of European civil protection, because climate change threatens even Sweden, because last year we also had many dead in Portugal. We must rebuild the Eye, and quickly, with European funds but without private closed beaches, without arbitrary construction, without the bureaucracy described by Mr Kyrkos. That's what we have to do together and together.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: Mr President, perhaps I am the first non-Greek speaker. Of course, I think it is very good that we observed one minute's silence together at the beginning of this session. What happened to the people and immediately afterwards, as indicated by the Commissioners, is now about assistance. The first, acute help is also well provided. Secondly, it is about building up, and that is what we are talking about now: solidarity fund and other reprioritization.  But there are some questions behind that – and they have also been asked, such as how we can do more about prevention now. How can we ensure that there are fewer deaths in these situations? I remember the debate we had here about the floods through a large bed, also in Greece, in which it was built! Yes, you can prevent that at some point. There's a lot more you can do. It's a good thing we're getting a resolution. We'll look at the text. The EPP would like to do that. Secondly, in October we will have a broader debate on the right balance between prevention and curation, between compassion that we like to show, but also the prevention of this kind of almost annual occurrence.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, let me not repeat myself, the actions we are proposing on the tragedy have already been described and will also be contained in the resolution we are tabling. Ladies and gentlemen, President Tajani, referring to the victims of the recent disasters, dared, and spoke of seeking and attribution of responsibility. I believe that it is our highest obligation to respond to this imperative 'why', to make every possible and institutional effort to respond. We must demand, at least once, that those who have failed to do their duty be held accountable and held accountable, ladies and gentlemen. To those who have neglected to do their duty but also, above all, to those who knowingly implement policies that endanger human lives and property. Because the austerity policies that are being implemented have victims of the social state, welfare and the protection of citizens. The fire in Mati, with its tragic account, proves it hard. Cuts to civil protection personnel and infrastructure to save Greece and sustainability of debt. Reading reality, ladies and gentlemen, is not a political game and a cave. Ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow the Greek Prime Minister will be here to discuss the future of Greece. Please ask him directly what was his fault and 98 of his fellow citizens will never be able to participate in the vision of Europe.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Mr President, I think there are phenomena, such as the greenhouse effect, that are burdening the situation for everyone and, especially in Greece, we also have arbitrary construction. They are two aggravating factors that expose us to greater risks. However, these factors should not be used as an alibi, but should motivate us to better organise, prevent better and coordinate when the problem occurs. I think that in Mati we have reached 98 dead because, in addition to the factors I mentioned, the administrative disorganisation, which is particularly characteristic of recent years, and the reduction of the Public Investment Programme were combined. We have a paradox: that the public investment programme should be reduced and that the objectives should not be achieved, that expenditure should ultimately be even lower than the reduced targets. What's bothering me? Obviously we want European solidarity and obviously we will support every effort to deal with the consequences. But we had a similar fire in Portugal in 2017 and then the interior minister resigned, apologizing. We had an accident in Bulgaria with 18 dead in a car accident and three ministers resigned, apologizing for the state of the road network. In Greece we have a problem, a tragedy, without politicians and administrators.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my solidarity with those affected, victims and survivors. At the same time, I am not happy about how this debate, which was supposed to be a European debate, has become quite a national debate and I would therefore like to participate in it from a European point of view. If you find yourself as a citizen in such a difficult, difficult situation, what do you expect from your state? Undoubtedly, of course, aid and from the Union, which is supposed to declare some unity, some help and solidarity for these states, you also expect help. I believe that, of course, the aid must arrive quickly and effectively. We have a specific fund here, the Solidarity Fund, which provides this assistance. This fund has also been changed by the regi committee's activities, the conditions set in this parliamentary term so that the assistance is truly effective. I'd like to join the call: "He who gives fast gives, he gives twice," says one proverb. Let us be truly effective at that European level, let us help in prevention, let us have sufficient allocation in this fund. But I don't think politicization at the national level belongs here.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Mr President, I would like to express my deepest condolences to the families of the people who have lost their lives unjustly. In the Mati area of East Attica, hundreds of families were destroyed. The intense natural phenomena and the fatal lack of state officials have led to tragic results. As I asked for in my question, European aid and assistance must be immediate, both in infrastructure to avoid new disasters with winter floods and to repair the damage, so that the inhabitants of the region can get back on their feet. Friends and friends, following last year's deadly fires in Portugal, the Commission presented the proposal to reorganise the European Civil Protection Mechanism. There is provision for strengthening prevention mechanisms and also for the creation of the rescEU, a pan-European reservoir of tools, such as fire helicopters and aeroplanes, so that there is immediate intervention and not voluntary as it is today. It is regrettable, however, that we have been following in recent days, particularly after the latest dramatic events, that the Council is once again opting for the distortion of the Commission's proposal by introducing punitive logics which will, in fact, exclude countries from using the mechanism we are going to create today.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: Mr President, I too would like to express my condolences to the families of the victims. Ladies and gentlemen, the tragic account of the deadly fire in Mati, this summer in Greece, is not only explained by climate change and the special weather conditions at that time in that region. It is the responsibility of the state authorities to deal with this fire. There are political responsibilities that have not been assumed. Prosecutors in Greece are investigating any criminal responsibilities. But here, ladies and gentlemen, we also have the real dimension of the memorial policies imposed on Greece, namely the cut in public expenditure that has left 4 000 posts in the Fire Brigade uncovered, which have deprived the Greek public administration of important infrastructures and means of managing natural disasters. The disaster is unprecedented in human casualties, in homes and in infrastructure. I have already put a question to the Commission, which I repeat on the occasion of this debate today, in order to take immediate measures to give practical support and expression of solidarity to those affected by the disaster and to demonstrate the greatest possible flexibility - there is the precedent, it has been mentioned - to activate Community funds to help those affected and affected areas.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to express my condolences once again to the relatives of the victims of this unspeakable tragedy and to wish a speedy recovery to the burn victims, some of whom are still hospitalized. No one disputes that on that black day the conditions were such as to encourage the rapid spread of the fire and leave little room for reaction to the authorities. Unfortunately, however, the authorities have not taken advantage of these margins. On the contrary, they have shown criminal negligence and oligopoly. Cars were not safely regulated in the surrounding areas and, instead of evacuating the area, they sent people from Marathon Avenue to Mati, which led to such a high number of casualties. While they knew about the weather conditions that would prevail, there was not the slightest preparation. Moreover, on the day of the disaster there was not the necessary coordination of all those responsible. At the regional level, the regional governor concerned and, at the municipal level, each mayor are responsible. Therefore the responsibilities of the Region of Attica are enormous, as are the Municipality of Marathon. Fire forces were stationed at the front of Kinetta, coming from East Attica, so that when the fire broke out in Mati, there were insufficient forces and the first to rush to tackle the fire were volunteers. What we are asking all Greeks urgently is to assign the responsibilities to those responsible and at the same time to take the necessary measures so as not to repeat tragedies like this in the Eye.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, I, in turn, extend my condolences to the families of those wronged in Mati Attica and wish a speedy recovery to those who are still injured. The biblical disaster, which occurred in this area which is very close to Athens, has enabled us to reflect on certain things and, despite the fact that we cannot practice politics, micropolitics if you want, on corpses, the elementary respect for the memory of those who have died requires us to reflect on the responsibilities and to ask that the Greek government be relieved of its pathogenicity and incompetence. Because its responsibilities are enormous and must be attributed both to it as a whole and individually to those who had an obligation to carry out the task entrusted to them by society. On the other hand, it is a first-class opportunity for the European Union to show solidarity, to help Greece financially and to try to ease the suffering of those who are still alive.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the tragedy in Mati, of the 98 dead and hundreds of injured, was a heralded crime of the timeless policy of governments - and of today -that degrade forest protection and firefighting, which commercialise the land without comprehensive civil protection planning. Commissioner Cređu, in her reply to the MEPs of the Jrc, cynically ruled out the possibility of compensation for those affected by stating that compensation for damage to private property is not eligible either under the ERDF or from the European Union Solidarity Fund. It is not eligible for the European Union, on the basis of the cost-benefit policy obviously, to compensate fire-fighters, but only to revitalise local economies, as it notes in its reply. In other words, it seems that the criterion is always profit and that is why flood defences are not selected, because, after their completion, they do not bring added value, as you say, to the European Union. In the face of these inadequate measures by the government and the European Union, following the deadly fire, workers are stepping up and strengthening their fight to claim immediate compensation from local residents and professionals at one hundred per cent of the total damage and meeting all their immediate and pressing needs.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is, of course, very sad to have to discuss this tragedy, but at the same time it is our duty to stand ready with the Member States and help them in these sad moments, and that is what we are doing. Last year’s experience with simultaneous forest fires showed that the current EU Civil Protection Mechanism, based on voluntary offers, has reached its limit. Last year the problems were primarily in Portugal, but also at the same time in France and in other countries, and we have seen a repeat this year with simultaneous fires in Greece, Sweden and Latvia. We have been facing multiple crises in numerous countries at the same time and, as a result, our Member States cannot always provide assistance to other Member States at the crucial moment. That is precisely why the Commission proposes to strengthen its civil protection system and create the mechanism that we call RescEU. RescEU establishes at European Union level a limited number of well—defined, own-operation capacities as a safety net to be deployed in response to a request by a Member State when existing capacities are overwhelmed. What used to be considered a type of natural disaster affecting only the south of Europe is now present, as you know, in the north too, in Sweden and in Latvia. We have also had wildfires in Greenland, and this means that what has been sensed here is true: climate change is real, it is happening, it is creating new realities on the ground, and we must adapt to them. That is why, as I said, the Commission proposed a new initiative last November to strengthen our collective capabilities to respond to natural disasters, with prevention and preparation as the fundamental pillar. Through RescEU we want to help Member States to do more on prevention and to foster a culture of prevention. We also want to help Member States, through European funds, to boost their own national capacities in respect of the various risks they face. Trilogues on these proposals started last week, and we need to conclude these discussions by November this year in order to have RescEU up and running by the summer season, which I think is essential. On what my portfolio covers, as I said at the beginning of the last debate, I was in constant contact with all the authorities – local and regional – and with Members of the European Parliament. We hoped for an assessment of the damage to indicate where we can help, but we are still waiting and it seems that this event is not eligible, according to the legislation agreed and voted by the co—legislators – by the European Parliament and the Council. However, as I said, I am ready to discuss with the Greek authorities the possibility of advance payment and also of changing some operational programmes. We have the envelope for Attica and we can change operational programmes at the request of the Member States if they want to transfer some of the money for reconstruction. We are ready to do whatever is possible to help, according to the legislation we have in place.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Motions for resolutions to be tabled pursuant to Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure will be announced at a later date. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, September 13, 2018.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the short presentation of the report by Jana Žitňanská, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on pathways for the reintegration of workers into quality jobs after an accident or illness (2017/2277(INI))(A8-0208/2018).

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: I don't know what I' – Let me first explain briefly the reasons that led to this report being created. Very often, in fact, we have become accustomed to this, we are talking about an ageing European population and increasing numbers of chronic diseases or disabilities. However, we are talking a little less about how much this change will affect the way we work and what impact it will have on the working environment for all of us. I am therefore very happy that, among my colleagues here in Parliament, I have found enough willingness to formulate ways of countering this challenge more actively and together. In preparing the report, I met many experts not only in Brussels, but also in Slovakia. I was interested in the view of the state administration, employers, patient organizations. I thank them for their valuable advice and recommendations. I would also like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, advisers and secretariat of the Committee on Social Affairs and Employment for their excellent cooperation, patience, helpfulness and materiality. Together, we found that approaches to returning to work after illness are often different, and the way in which individual states help their citizens is also different. Nevertheless, there are approaches that we can all support and share together. Unfortunately, there are still many cases where things are not working, people are unaided and states, municipalities or employers are not taking the necessary action. This is a space that we should fill, and I believe that this report can also be helpful. The added value of our work, work from the European Parliament, is to help Member States develop preventive measures in particular, to give careful priority to so-called early intervention when a worker's health deteriorates, thus preventing more complex health problems. Prevention is key. I would also like to mention here that, although chronic diseases, for example, are more likely to be associated with older age, although this is not the case in many cases either, the report also does not forget about mental health, excessive stress and mental problems. They are also part of our lives, and where necessary, we need to talk about them out loud, help eliminate prejudice and improve understanding of mental health. I did not just prepare the report from the table, but I tried to get the view of the people in practice, the people who tried to return to work after illness or disability. These discussions have left me with a great need for better institutional cooperation between all relevant stakeholders, as well as the need for a personalised approach. The occupational rehabilitation of workers consists of three different aspects: the first is medical, the second is occupational and the third is social. Successful rehabilitation and return to work involve all three, and it is important that our report reflects this approach. In the report, we encourage Member States to take an example from good practices and approaches, while at the same time trying to identify areas where the European Union can bring added value and know-how in order to further support policies that will ultimately help Member States to enable workers to be reintegrated into the labour market. It is just as important to me that by successfully practising returning to work after illness, we would be able to give far more people than today the hope of a more dignified and independent life. We are facing two major challenges today. The first one is more technical. We need to improve standards, methods, prevention, cooperation. The other task is about changing perceptions. We need to significantly reclaim the perception of people with health problems or disabilities by the majority society. I believe that this report will be one of the necessary steps towards these objectives.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, colleagues, I would like to thank our colleague Žitňanská for the very comprehensive report she has presented. It is clear that returning to work is in the interest of both the individual and society. Work has a positive effect on the psyche of a sick person and can also strengthen, allow his recovery. Moreover, it allows a person to reintegrate into society, to make a living and to feel the importance that he is still needed in life, and this, of course, also benefits his rehabilitation.  It is necessary to emphasize the possibility of using flexible forms of work, work from home. I am glad that this report emphasises precisely these new forms of work, which can be used in rehabilitation and enabling the return and integration of variously disabled people into society. And I would also like to remind you of the inclusion in volunteering activities, because these people can find very good employment there. So thank you and I support this report.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first of all like to thank my colleague Žitňanská for the report, which touches on a very important and yet often taboo social issue, which is the return of people to work after a long illness. The report points out that this issue has a broad context not only for resocialisation, e.g. people who are long-term ill, after permanent injuries, workers with different types of disabilities, but also because of the changing structure of the labour market as the population ages. The report stresses the need for an individual approach and support for employees, but also, for example, adapting the working environment, removing barriers. There is no reason for a stick to break over people because of their injuries or long-term illness, whether because of physical or psychological barriers in their environment. It is also about employers' responsibility towards their employees. Thank you and once again congratulations on this report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the right to work of every person is sacred and inalienable because, with his work, a man not only secures a living for himself and his family, but at the same time feels a mental balance and is socially established. For this reason, every state must ensure work for its citizens, and at the same time decent wages and social benefits. In addition, the basic obligation of each State is to ensure the smooth reintegration into work of those who have been temporarily removed from it, either as a result of an accident or illness. It is immoral to use these people just to work and then forget about them. We have an obligation to integrate all returning workers into society and at the same time to create those conditions that confirm and ensure their moral dignity and recognition.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I, too, would like to applaud mrs Žitňanská's report and say that it is undoubtedly fair for this House to rail against forms of discrimination, against the exclusion or stigmatisation of certain persons. Prevention and early intervention is one of the issues raised by my colleague. There are a number of instruments that this report is considering, I am subscribe. Undoubtedly, adapting the workplace is one of the smallest measures than to lose a given worker. I think that there are still a number of measures, e.g. transfer to another workplace or, in agreement with the employee, to designate a different type of work for him. This is particularly important for our elderly fellow citizens and, of course, for citizens who have problems such as mental health problems. And in that next toolkit, which is listed in the chapter "Return to work", I would really emphasize the reintegration and individual approach to every employee who is disadvantaged in this way.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
