text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European It would be nice to think that, following an accident at work or an occupational disease, the employer is working to reintegrate his employee, his unlucky employee, as much as possible, and we would think that this process is usually done in the spirit of friendliness, solidarity, love.  As a lawyer, I regret to say that this is far from typical. Moreover, it is typical for employers to deny liability and, as my colleague said in other contexts, legal assistance: – access to justice, access to justice – also in these kinds of labour disputes, and the enforcement of workers' rights in general – often, as opposed to employers – whether to reach a good deal or to enforce rights in an effective dispute. Thank you very much!

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I too want to stress the importance of the report and congratulate the rapporteur. Of course, I come from among employers and yes, it is extremely complicated, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, to support the costs of low productivity, because we have to recognise that people who do not have 100% working capacity cannot have the same yield. But here is the role of the states - and I must stress that it is important to develop social enterprises, to have compensation policies, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises employing people with low working capacity. Above all, we have to prevent, because in the end, it is important not to reach a very large number of people with stress, stress at work. I believe that there is a need for a lot of education here for employers to create jobs without further stressoning employees, and for those who no longer have the capacity to work, to focus on the policies of the Member States, but also of the Commission, to support programmes to compensate employers who focus on the integration and reintegration of the workforce which does not have a capacity for work of 100%.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for these constructive and valuable remarks. The Commission has put inclusive growth and social fairness at the core of its political agenda, and we are working hard to make sure that no one is left behind. I therefore welcome Ms Žitňanská’s report, and the Commission agrees that we need effective and concrete measures for workers returning to the labour market after injury and illness.  The prerequisite for successful reintegration into the labour market is ensuring the right to a healthy, safe and well-adapted working environment, as clearly recalled in the European Pillar of Social Rights. European Union legislation on occupational safety and health focuses on the legal obligation imposed on employers to assess all occupational risks on a case-by-case basis and to adapt work to the special needs of individuals. We have to bear in mind that Europe is confronted with an ageing working population with increasing work-related health problems, such as muscular-skeletal disorders and mental health conditions, so we need to face and address this reality. The European Union Strategic Framework on Health and Safety for the current programming period already proposes a number of measures to address demographic change and the ageing workforce. Besides, the 2017 Commission communication on ‘Safer and healthier work for all’ has put forward specific preventive and protective measures in accordance with the requirements of sensitive workers. Now, on the reintegration and rehabilitation of workers more specifically, I agree with you that measures allowing early return to work after an accident or disease are needed in order to avoid permanent exclusion. And, you are right, we should see the reintegration process as a new opportunity to benefit from workers’ skills, competence and experience. That is why we have the European Social Fund, on which Member States can already rely to help injured workers, for instance, to get back to work more quickly. For the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) the Commission is going further by proposing to include the health programme as a strand of the European Social Fund plus (ESF+) so health aspects are addressed in all social spending, and vice versa. To conclude, let me assure you that the Commission will continue, in cooperation with the European Agency for Safety and Health at Work, which is based in Bilbao, to raise awareness, develop practical guidance and promote the exchange of good practices. Once again, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work. This is an important contribution in defining the steps forward in the effective reintegration of workers recovering from injuries and illness.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: That concludes the point. The vote will take place on Tuesday, September 11, 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. The report highlights the need for policies to help workers re-enter the labour market, including the fact that the presence of older people in the workplace leads to less turnover of staff, whose productivity benefits from wider skills and experiences, better commitment in the workplace and sometimes superior performance than young workers , particularly in terms of conflict resolution. The proposals in this report are common sense and are in line with what is already being practiced in France, and will therefore not cause an upheaval in the current legislation. On the contrary, it will be able to participate in the fight against the social dumping of Member States whose current legislation is much less restrictive in terms of the policy of reintegration of workers following an injury or illness. However, we condemn this interference in our national legislation, interference that can block future progress that France could decide.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the short presentation of the report by Pina Picierno, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on measures to prevent and combat bullying and sexual harassment in the workplace, in public places and in political life in the EU (2018/2055(INI)) (A8-0265/2018).

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we have been working on this report in committee for more than a year, and I am particularly proud of the result we have achieved. Proud because with this text, I believe, we are taking a great step forward in the fight against harassment and bullying of women. Proud because, thanks to this text, we can finally bring to the center of this debate and also of public opinion a problem that for decades has been minimized, for decades has been avoided in the name of an alleged possible diversity of sensitivity, and that instead, thanks to that global movement that has been called "MeToo" and that has brought to the center the denunciation of many women , has finally become a central issue. Every day women and girls are subjected to violence, harassed, harassed in the workplace, in the bar, in the cinema, in the park, in the gym, and this long list of places could really go on forever, unfortunately. And to these places we must add, unfortunately, another new public place, which is the virtual public place, it is social networks, it is chats, it is websites, it is blogs, they are those virtual places where, unfortunately, verbal and psychological violence materializes dramatically more and more. At that time, in the FEMM Committee, we wanted to draw attention to these events, to these new events that are taking place, to emphasize this aspect that is increasingly appearing in our daily chronicles. Because all kinds of violence, all kinds of harassment have very serious consequences, it has psychological or physical consequences, as demonstrated precisely by the cases of suicide of girls who have very often been victims of revenge porn or digital bullying online, and who have not been able to cope with the burden of shame of what they had suffered. It is for them, for all the women who have been harassed, for all the women who are harassed, that we are carrying on this battle. And we call on the Commission to make a greater effort, Commissioner, as the European executive. We want a directive to finally be proposed which will standardise the fight against gender-based violence, and we want this directive to have a clear, uniform definition of what it means to be harassed or harassed. Above all, we want a clear definition of what a public place means today because, as we said before, technologies have changed this concept by creating new virtual squares, where verbal violence no longer has control, mainly because people feel practically invincible and unpunishable in these virtual environments, where one can easily hide behind a nickname to feel untouchable. So we also ask for more education, we also ask for more attention on this aspect, because it is precisely from school, which is the first public place where children begin to confront reality, with their schoolmates, that we must begin, educating gender equality, educating equality, respect and awareness, because respect is due to everyone and because the sex of the person cannot do it better or worse than another. I would therefore like to end by thanking once again all my fellow Members who have worked on this text. We are sure that it will enable us to take an important step forward.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Good evening, I greet you warmly. I greet you especially after the holiday. I understand that you are fully verve for work.  Submissions from the room

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Picierno, for her work. Thanks in particular, we have before us a text that can be supported by all the political groups. In particular, I would like to point out that the report also draws attention to the bullying of pregnant women and mothers in the workplace. The resulting text is balanced because it relies on the imperative of human dignity enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which is based on a Christian understanding of man. If we really want to eradicate sexual harassment and bullying in the workplace once and for all, we need to talk more about being equal in our dignity as people. This ethical postulat is the real reason why no one has the right to harass or bully another person. Not the Istanbul Convention, laws or corporate rules.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, sexual harassment and abuse are still one of the most odious forms of violence and violation of human rights. They occur in the workplace, as in public life and also in the digital sphere. According to a study by fra agency, one in five women between the ages of eighteen and twenty-nine have experienced sexual harassment online. The European institutions, Commissioner, must therefore give a strong impetus to the Member States fully implementing the Istanbul Convention, harmonising their gender-based legislation in order to tackle the new forms of sexual harassment and bullying in the virtual space, which cause victims long-term psychological consequences and which in some cases have led very young victims to take their own lives.  Educational and prevention campaigns are also needed in schools to spread a new culture focused on respect for women and to prepare young people for responsible use of the Internet and social media. We also need forms of cooperation with Internet service providers to take concrete measures to protect consumers and enable them to report cases of abuse and persecution.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, many people, especially online, have been subjected to abuse for a different opinion, and to humiliate them, their gender or physical characteristics are targeted. Such behavior is inadmissible, so education, prevention and adequate legal solutions must work on its elimination. But on the other hand, under the infestation of radical feminists, the definition of harassment and harassment is so widened that any courtship becomes undesirable. Even some world-renowned feminists have spoken out about this problem. The boundary is important to set, one must know what is really for each conviction and should be legally sanctioned, and what falls within the normal human communication that at a certain point can be laborious or boring, but certainly, it is not about abuse. If this boundary is not clear, people will be further moved away under the pressure of poor legal regulation and case law, which will leave serious consequences for our societies.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, sexual harassment and enforcement, especially in the workplace, is an unacceptable and reprehensible mentality and practice, but it is interwoven with the nature of man. It was in force, it is valid and it will be in force in the future, unless the necessary measures are taken. Above all, this mentality is expressed and based on the philosophy of some men that, by acting in this way, they either self-confirm or dominate their victim. Of course, they are indifferent both to the violation of his human rights and to the reduction of his personality. But much more, they don't care about the emotional and psychological traumas they create to their victim. This must therefore be addressed and, in order to be tackled, young men must be trained not to consider this action to be either a sign of enforcement. It's actually a covert form of cowardice. If we do not move in this direction, no matter how many definitions we give, no matter how many analyses we do, we will not achieve the desired result.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I consider it important that the humiliation of workers should in no way be tolerated. Various forms of bullying, mobbing, these also occur in employment within the framework of public administration or politics. And I am glad that the European Parliament is trying to address the various cases that have also occurred here. I would also like to thank our colleague Elisabeth Morin-Chartier, who has advocated dealing with such very unpleasant and sad cases.  In the end, in the Czech Republic, we had a minister who eventually had to resign for humiliating his employees, but it took some months. I consider it important that society remains sensitive to what it is to humiliate people, and here it is precisely prevention that is needed, which was also mentioned by the pre-speaking Anna Záborská, i.e. education, ethical education, simply to remain sensitive to these issues.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and say from the outset that I particularly support paragraph 17, namely that of having a directive, Commissioner, because, of course, we are not starting to work against harassment now, but the results are not also the statistical data that have been shown here and are also contained in the report sure, they're not the real ones, because there's a sub-reporting. Let us think especially of the countryside, of villages, where women endure violence and do not have the courage to report domestic violence or violence in the workplace because there is no possibility of protection afterwards, there is no shelter, there is no possibility of not continuing in permanent form.  That is why I think this report is welcome, but it must have a purpose. On the one hand, having programmes, school curricula, education, it is obvious, but we have to have sanctions, because anything for nothing we are putting into a directive or a law if there are no very harsh penalties in the case of sexual harassment, and in the situation of moral harassment. I am glad that there is a chapter with political life, because we have to be fair to ourselves - and in political life there is harassment, and we draw attention to political leaders.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, thank you to the rapporteur for a good report and for the many important points of view that you have raised. Although women in Finland have been allowed to vote for more than 100 years in different elections, we too have much room for improvement in equality between women and men, including in politics. I've been in positions of trust for over thirty years. Before I was elected to the European Parliament, I was a Member of Parliament in the Finnish Parliament for eight years. Officially, equality between women and men is recognised, but women are still made invisible in politics. We, too, have chasses, especially older men, who even publicly disparate and mock women who have made careers in politics, even their personal qualities, claiming them to be cold, cynical and humourless, for example. Men in Finnish politics easily team up for common hobbies, such as golf and various sauna clubs, where things are agreed in advance between men. I am afraid that this is also the case in many other countries, so we will not run out of work on equality.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Unfortunately, so-called politically correct speech is so widespread and so disturbing that people often wave it away even when it comes to very serious phenomena and real phenomena, such as sexual harassment.  If we were not living in the disturbing and false world of political correctness, for example, the "Me too" campaign could have had the consequence – a good consequence, as my dear colleague referred to me here – that men would have begun to think about what modern male roles would be like in the modern world. That a real man doesn't need to harass a woman, and that a real man can distinguish between consensual, consensual compliments, flirting, courtship, and humiliation, violence, violations of human dignity. That's what we should finally be talking about, and finally our fellow men should be talking about it. Thank you very much!

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Mr President, sexual harassment is a form of violence and it is the most extreme form of gender—based discrimination. Up to 55% of women have been sexually harassed in the EU. This is totally unacceptable and intolerable. We must adopt and ensure the full implementation of legal instruments, including the Istanbul Convention, to eliminate gender—based violence across Europe. Unfortunately, because of the low awareness, social stereotyping, fear and shame associated with talking to other people, women are always reluctant to report these cases.  One point I would like to raise is the importance of education, which I believe should be a fundamental tool in avoiding and eliminating this misconduct, changing mindsets and reducing cultural tolerance of sexism and sexual harassment. Education programmes and debates should be introduced for both girls and boys, as should information about prevention and measures against sexual harassment, and victims’ rights – such as how to seek legal aid – must be extended to our children at an early stage.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the Commission, I would like to thank Parliament and, of course, the rapporteur for this excellent report and for keeping this topic high on the agenda. Unfortunately sexual harassment and mobbing are an unacceptable, yet widespread, form of behaviour in our European society. As has been said, we know this happens everywhere: at work, in schools and universities, on the street, in public transport, online, at festivals and at sport and other events. The world woke up last year with the ‘Me Too’ movement and it was literally a wake—up call. People finally saw the huge extent of sexism, harassment, abuse and violence that women and girls are facing every day in society. Around half of the women in the European Union experience verbal, physical or online sexual harassment. In the case of women in higher management or professional occupations, such as lawyers and doctors, the proportion balloons to 75%. We have to change the perception in our societies that harassing a woman is normal, acceptable behaviour. We all have this responsibility, whether we are politicians, police officers, teachers, employees or operators of internet platforms. Women should not feel that it is unsafe for them to travel, to go to work, to be out in the street or to be active online. How many of you are ready to go on foot to your hotels tonight when we finish at 11 o’clock? I do not feel safe doing so even though it would be healthy. Having said this, it is worth reminding you that our efforts to end violence and harassment against women have not just started recently. More than 20 years ago, Parliament was instrumental when we set up the Daphne Programme. Besides, we have been working for decades in the European Union to develop legislation, policy and concrete grassroots actions to prevent violence and to support victims. We have to continue on this path, which includes the European Union’s signing of the Istanbul Convention last year and the current process of conclusion. Having been a Member of the European Parliament for eight years, and now a Commissioner for three years, I can tell you that this journey is slow and long. We in the Commission are working closely with the Council towards EU accession to the Convention, but we really call on those Member States which have not yet ratified it to proceed to do so without further delay. To conclude, I would like to mention that the Commission has had an anti—harassment policy in place since 2006. It combines prevention and information to all staff, as well as training, with reactive measures to deal with the situation of workplace conflict and harassment. I want to reiterate that the Commission is fully committed to the fight against all forms of gender—based violence, including sexual harassment. Let me be very clear: even a single case of harassment will always be one case too many. Thank you for your attention and for your hard work. Hopefully, our daughters, our nieces and we ourselves will be safer from now on.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you very much Commissioner. I ask you to stay with us, we very much need you to the next point.  I close the debate.  The vote will take place on Tuesday 11 September 2018.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. – Social awareness of sexual and psychological harassment at work has increased considerably in recent times. Successful campaigns, such #MeToo, have focused on female victims, but we should not assume that bullying perpetrators are always men or that victims are always women. International evidence shows that the percentage of male victims of harassment is not trivial and quite likely exceeds 10% (for example, 17% of complaints collected by the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission are men; and, according to an ILO-cited French survey, 8% of women and 7% of men reported harassment at work). Experts also indicate that male victims of bullying tend to report their experiences less due to social stereotypes, and that studies focusing on male victimization are lacking. Positive change in social attitudes, towards a lower tolerance for harassment and greater recognition of women's rights, should be used to extend recognition to all victims regardless of gender or sexual orientation. I regret, in this regard, that this report ignores male victimisation.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Brian Hayes, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on relations between the EU and third countries on the regulation and supervision of financial services (2017/2253(INI)) (A8-0263/2018).

name: Brian HAYES
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I welcome the Commissioner to our discussion this evening. At the outset, I would like to thank all the rapporteurs who worked on this own-initiative report with me over the course of the last number of months, and also to thank my colleagues in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, who voted for this report in such large numbers just before the summer. I think we have arrived at a good settlement on what is not only a crucially important issue for the European Union and its relationship with third countries but also a crucially important issue for financial stability within the European Union and in the relationships we have with others. I also want to recognise that this is a forward-looking report, trying to map out, and to achieve a considered view by Parliament about, the future equivalence arrangements that should exist in terms of our relationship with third countries. I welcome the fact that the Commission in 2017 put forward a review of the equivalence framework. It is right and proper that we should look at our procedures in place, and equally it is right and proper that Parliament should have some role in terms of shaping that review and making sure that we have a meaningful input into its final outworkings. We in the European Union have worked hard at reducing risk, especially since the crisis: reducing market fragmentation, and also ensuring that we have an international standard in terms of our financial regulation here within the European Union. We have international responsibility for ensuring that the international order, in terms of rule-making and rule-taking, is adopted not just within the European Union, at an inter-institutional level, but also by all Member States of the Union. So having a rules-based system sends a strong message to those members of the international community that have a third-country relationship with us about what we expect in that. It is also fair to say that, in trying to reach that international best standard, Europe is doing its bit to reduce any of the systemic risks and threats that have been built up over past decades. There is a clear advantage in Europe being a standard bearer for good financial regulation globally and that is something we always need to keep in mind when talking about this issue. We also need to recognise that the existing equivalence regime is really a technical regime in which the Commission has extraordinary power, and we need to recognise that, in many cases, the Commission gets those decisions right on case-by-case deliberation of the issues that come before it, and on a file-by-file basis. But that’s not to say that the framework cannot be improved – it would be a ridiculous position if there were no possibility of the regime for equivalence being improved. What we have tried to set out in this report are areas where we can improve the system in the future: areas of greater transparency in the Commission’s dealings with Parliament; how Parliament can assess and analyse some of these decisions; and a monitoring role for Parliament, making sure that decisions are taken by way of delegated acts, making sure that Parliament is fully aware of the circumstances and the position contained in decisions. I haven’t mentioned Brexit because this report is not about Brexit, despite the fact that, when we first embarked on the own-initiative report, people were obsessed by Brexit. This is about setting our house in order, making sure that we have a system in place for the future, and making sure that system is transparent for all, and applies the best possible international standards in our dealings with third countries.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner. Europe has been making a special effort to have a stable and secure financial sector for a few years now. The crisis reminded us that banks and financial institutions were poorly regulated and poorly supervised. Europe has been working for years to have a robust financial system that can provide services to consumers and is also particularly stable. And, therefore, it is very important that financial institutions providing services to the European market comply with equivalent regulations, with controls that can be approved for European regulation.  And for this there are equivalence systems.  Equivalence systems that the Commission manages but which need to be more transparent; there has to be stricter control on the part of the European Parliament and the model has to be revised because in the coming months we will have to negotiate a future agreement with the UK, which also makes it particularly important.  I would like to congratulate Hayes on the work and this House which will vote on a very important report tomorrow.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the Commission I would like to thank rapporteur Hayes for his report on this work. I welcome the large consensus among political groups. Indeed, it is in our interests to have robust international cooperation, matching cross—border business activity in this area. Of course, it increases competition, consumer and investor protection and accelerates innovation in the sector and it helps public authorities ensure financial viability in the European Union. You know very well, honourable Members, that the European Union financial system is a very open to financial service providers from many parts of the world. The European Union has adopted more than two hundred positive decisions in financial services, covering more than thirty non—EU jurisdictions. You know that that the equivalence process requires that we look at each third country in a regulatory and supervisory framework separately, sector by sector, and we do this in a proportionate and risk—sensitive manner. In this respect I welcome that the report confirms that the equivalence is the most suitable and flexible tool for relations with third countries in financial services. Of course, it is not perfect, but compared to other alternatives, equivalence preserves the autonomy of EU decision—making and provides powerful incentives for regulatory and supervisory cooperation at international level.  The Commission agrees with the report in the same areas. The European Union framework for third—country equivalence should be further enhanced. In this regard, a number of important proposals were adopted last year. For example, the proposal to amend the European market infrastructure regulation differentiates between the treatment of systematically important third—country centre counterparties and the treatment of non—systematically important ones. The proposal also shows in which circumstances we would need to go beyond equivalence as a last resort. Finally, we propose to clarify the role of the European Supervisory Authorities in preparing equivalence decisions. We also propose that these authorities assume greater responsibility for monitoring the situation in third countries on with the Commission has taken an equivalence decision.  Now regarding transparency, the Commission agrees that the transparency of the process for granting equivalence can be improved. Over the past three years, we have sought to raise transparency and awareness. For example, in February 2017, we published a staff document to explain our approach. The Commission is ready to come to the Parliament and keep its Members closely informed. Besides, in some of our latest proposals we have put forward the possibility for Parliament and the Council to play a more prominent role in equivalence policy by scrutinising delegating acts which set out detailed equivalence criteria to be applied to the Commission. Lastly, the Commission agrees that equivalence will play an important role in shaping the European Union’s regulatory and economic relations with the UK once it has become a third country. Let me conclude by welcoming once again, the work of all of you and the work of the European Parliament. The Commission now, of course, counts on Parliament and the Council, as co—legislators, to continue moving as swiftly as possible in the coming months to adopt the on-going proposal. Thank you very much for your attention and for your work.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.  The vote will take place on Tuesday 11 September 2018.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – Equivalence is a useful tool for promoting international regulatory convergence, which can lead to more competition in the EU's internal market on a level playing field, prevent regulatory arbitrage, protect consumers and investors, maintain the EU's financial stability and ensure coherence within the internal market. Equivalence also serves as an instrument to ensure fair and equal regulation and supervision between EU financial institutions and third-country financial institutions. Equivalence also works on a reciprocal basis: other jurisdictions give EU market participants access to their financial markets. This gives European companies the assurance that European rules and conditions apply in the third countries where they develop their economic activity and provide their financial goods and services. Since the financial crisis, more than 40 new EU financial rules have been adopted. Of these 40 new acts, 15 contain third country clauses that allow the Commission, on behalf of the EU, to unilaterally decide whether the rules in foreign jurisdictions can be considered equivalent. Unfortunately, the Commission has a wide margin of discretion in adopting equivalence decisions, far from any democratic control. This report calls for greater transparency and democratic control. This will allow equivalence decisions to be made that focus more on the priorities of Parliament and the citizens, and that is to be welcomed.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Jill Evans, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on linguistic equality in the digital age (2018/2028(INI)) (A8-0228/2018).

name: Jill EVANS
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, there is a Welsh proverb: ‘A nation without a language is a nation without a heart’ – Cenedl heb iaith, cenedl heb galon. It reflects the centrality of the language to people’s identity and culture. In the same way, Europe’s linguistic diversity is an integral element of European identity, reflected in the motto Unity in diversity. The EU has 500 million citizens, 24 official languages, five co-official languages and three alphabets, but some 60 other languages are also part of the EU’s heritage, including sign languages, which are included in my report.  The EU has played an important role in supporting linguistic diversity and encouraging the promotion and protection of minority and lesser—spoken languages. This is in Article 22 of the Charter for Fundamental Rights. The Committee on Culture and Education agreed that we must ensure comprehensive EU—level legal protection for regional and minority languages, recognising the collective rights of national and linguistic minorities in the digital world. Because when we go online, we find a world where many languages are at risk of extinction. New technologies like Siri and Alexa are changing the way we live our lives, but are available in just a few languages. As this technology gets more widely used, the speakers of other languages are being left behind. To help address this problem my report calls on the Commission to bring forward a range of measures, including: allocating the specific area of multilingualism and language technology to the portfolio of one Commissioner; establishing a large—scale, long—term funding programme for research and development and innovation, as well as establishing a European language technology platform, and extending the digital language diversity project; supporting education policies to ensure that the next generation of Europeans will lead the way in this field, as well as encouraging companies to take the business opportunities that this would present. Our multilingualism is a great asset, an opportunity, and at the same time is one of the EU’s greatest challenges. The impetus from my report was a STOA study entitled ‘Language equality in the digital age – Towards a human language project’ which showed the social and economic consequences of language barriers. In fact, we see the technology gap widening between the large, well—resourced languages and others, even some official languages.  The network of experts on language technologies –META—NET– warns that at least 21 European languages are in danger of extinction in the digital world. So we must act, and urgently. This is a huge opportunity for the EU to demonstrate a real commitment to language equality which will benefit all its citizens, to share ideas and good practice, and I am proud that researchers in Wales, such as in Canolfan Bedwyr at Bangor University, are leading the way.  Finally, can I thank the shadow rapporteurs for their enthusiastic cooperation, my assistant, Cai Elis, for his excellent work on this report, as well as our Group staff, colleagues in the Committee on Industry, Trade and Research, the committee secretariat and all the experts who advised me during the process. It is clear this is an issue of huge interest.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – In the digital age, the role of languages is redefined and the usefulness of each language is raised even more prominently. It is therefore very important for Europe to see linguistic diversity as a value and to allocate serious resources to the practical implementation of linguistic equality. Modern technology is now a solution to this, and the European Union can use the potential competitive disadvantages of its linguistic fragmentation to its advantage, playing a global leadership role in this area.  In particular, the report draws attention to the importance of comprehensive legal protection of some 60 European regional and minority languages and stresses the recognition of the collective rights of national and linguistic minorities in the digital world. It calls it extremely important to provide mother tongue education to those who speak official and unofficial languages of the EU. This is an area where some Member States do not seem to be doing everything possible to promote linguistic diversity and are even blocking it by all means. This kind of attitude does not in any way help the EU achieve its objectives and can therefore be regarded as strongly anti-EU.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on her draft report. It is very detailed and contains references to sign languages, the preferred language of the deaf in Europe.  Our society is digitising very quickly and it is important that our language skills are preserved. This is especially true for sign languages where displacement is imminent for some smaller sign languages in the EU because of scale and insufficient financial resources. We must therefore find ways to allow all the deaf people in the EU to participate in and benefit from the single digital market in their own sign language.  That is why I wholeheartedly support the report on linguistic equality in the digital age. All languages, whether spoken or sign languages, must be treated equally.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - I congratulate the rapporteur on her report. Commissioner, the recognition by the European institutions of languages such as Galician and the languages of the peoples that make up the multi-national reality of some Member States is fundamental and cannot depend solely on the decisions of the States which oppress us as peoples as well.  The situation in my country is very serious. Only 30% of people aged 15 to 19 speak Galician, compared to 75% of people over the age of 75. In addition, Galician accounts for less than 0.01% of web content.  In the digital age, galician must be present in the network on equal terms, to allow Galician speakers to navigate the network with total normality in Galician.  I will support the report and ask the Commission to implement the necessary measures to implement it. I ask this Parliament to provide for the means for all and all of us to express ourselves in a pariful position in our own languages, which are called 'minority', but which in fact are hidden languages which have been lowered by the imposition of force for centuries to make them predominant.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: – Mr President, mr President, I would like to President. I would like to congratulate Mr President. rapporteur who prepared an excellent report. Multilingualism has long been identified as a barrier to the development of the European digital market, but so far only a small number of European Union countries have taken active action to address this problem. Over the last decades, the role of digital technologies in society has become increasingly influential. It affects not only our habits, language, but also culture and lifestyle.  Technology is the only possible way to meet the needs of Europe and its multilingual environment. I am pleased that this issue has finally set itself on the European political agenda. I call on the European Commission to take the initiative to implement the actions proposed in the report and to create a European mother tongue project as soon as possible, a clear and long-term programme for financing research, development and innovation. Only in this way will Europe be able to secure a leading position in the long term, not only in the field of language technology but also in artificial intelligence.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, colleagues, the diversity of culture and therefore languages in Europe is our great cultural value and the wealth that we must keep. At a time when the digitisation and use of these digital technologies is constantly accelerating, we also need to look at how access is ensured in these 24 official languages in the European Union, as used. And we have found that the official websites of the European Union in some cases, in some programmes, do not yet use official languages enough. I agree that English will undoubtedly become the main language of communication for communication, but if we want to ensure that the languages of those smaller nations that are less widely used, say at the common European level, are supported, then we must also ensure that they are accessible on the websites of the European institutions.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the Commission, I would like to thank the Parliament for the impressive work done for the initiative on language equality in the digital age and for the enriching views expressed by you, its Members. The report comes at a time when digital technologies are transforming our society and economy at an unprecedented pace, offering opportunities but also revealing barriers to multilingualism and language equality in the digital age. In highlighting the complexity brought about by language diversity and the fundamental importance of language technologies on the road to achieving language equality, the report provides food for thought for developing future actions. Language technologies are an essential component of any digital device or service we use nowadays. Continuous research, innovation and deployment in the area of language technologies can therefore bring us closer and closer towards multilingualism at an acceptable cost. Ensuring appropriate technological support for all European languages will also create jobs, growth and opportunities in the digital single market. It will enhance the quality of public services, and reinforce a stronger sense of unity and belonging throughout Europe. EU funding has already led to a number of results. For example, in the Moses machine translations system, an open research result that has been taken up by the Commission for its in—house system or the modern machine translation project which developed a neural system that automatically improves translations. To leverage the achievements, under the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), we will need to reinforce funding, research and education actions. The Commission has therefore submitted programme proposals for the next Multiannual Financial Framework, seeking funding to continue its work towards technology enabled language equality. Overall, I would like to remind you that the Commission is committed to working towards an inclusive union offering seamless access to digital services, products and content, irrespective of language or location. Union citizens, businesses and public administrations can enjoy the right to access such services, products and content without discrimination based on language. I think it is also very important to say that we are focusing on the exchange of good practice in the policy recommendation, as well as funding programmes such as Erasmus+ and Creative Europe. The Commission has also confirmed the actions of the Council of Europe’s European Centre for Modern Languages, aimed, among other things, at supporting teachers working with children from different linguistic backgrounds. Finally, the Commission raised awareness of the importance of language learning through public events like the European Day of Languages on 26 September and the national awards of the European Language Label for innovative language learning projects. To conclude, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Evans, once again for her valuable work. We share the view that overcoming language barriers in the digital environment is essential for an inclusive society, a vibrant digital single market and for unity in diversity.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.  The vote will take place on Tuesday 11 September 2018.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. If multilingualism is one of the riches of Europe, which is made up of often secular nation states, we must not be deluded, which is the fault of this text, about the possibilities offered by language technologies to meet the challenge. These cannot replace language learning and, in this respect, Barcelona's ambitious objectives for the mastery of two foreign languages are struggling to materialize. Moreover, Member States have exclusive jurisdiction over their language strategies, and the requirement of bilingualism is not uniform everywhere. For the most prohibitive flaw of this report is its interference in the competences of the Member States, particularly in the field of education. Not only is it unacceptable to equate 'migrant languages' with European minority languages, but it is intolerable to claim to determine their use within the school system. Finally, I note that before interfering in the language policies of the Member States, the European Union should set an example in its own institutions, where the primacy of English continues to increase despite the impending Brexit.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Heidi Hautala, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on the transparent and responsible management of natural resources in developing countries: the issue of forests (2018/2003(INI)) (A8-0249/2018).

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, nobody should deny the urgency of addressing and tackling climate change, which has become a question for the very existence of humanity and our planet. We have increasing scientific evidence that forest cover is the one feasible option we have for combating climate change. Connected with that, we have to care for the soil, with its rich microbial life, which is the basis for life systems. However, we know that deforestation is currently the number two cause of greenhouse gas emissions. I believe that the EU has done a lot to try to protect forests worldwide, but it can do better. Namely, the EU already has excellent tools, which can be used to assist our partner countries on the way to better development. We have, for instance, the EU Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade instrument, which we call the Flegt Action Plan, and we have linked this with the Voluntary Partnership Agreements, which have proven to be indispensable tools in improving forest governance in partner countries. These Voluntary Partnership Agreements have brought stakeholders – I am talking about civil society, local and indigenous peoples, law-enforcement agents and governments – broadly together to the same negotiating table, to try to solve the difficult issue of deforestation so we can invest more in this important instrument in order to tackle corruption, which is often the cause of deforestation. We can also address the issue of so-called conflict timber just as we have addressed conflict minerals. I want to stress that there is a need for sufficient resources for these mechanisms and that Parliament should do more to secure those resources. What is urgently needed, however, is a coherent, all-encompassing EU action plan to stop deforestation and forest degradation. This is already several years overdue and I hope very much that the Commission will now take inspiration from this own-initiative report and will urgently open a genuine stakeholder consultation, which in turn will pave the way for the action plan against deforestation and forest degradation. I hope that Commissioner Mimica will continue to support these measures, which are outlined in the report. There are some striking examples of the fact that voluntary approaches to tackling deforestation in EU policy are not enough. For instance, in the cocoa sector, the EU is responsible for over 60% of global imports of cocoa, and the major part of the global cocoa supply is produced in Côte d’Ivoire and Ghana. However – you may not believe this, but it is true – in Côte d’Ivoire, for instance, 40% of production takes place on illegally converted forest land. I am sure that we, as European consumers, do not want to see this continue. I’m very glad, too, to hear private-sector voices being raised to call for mandatory due diligence in the cocoa supply chains, and, with this report, I hope we can address these requirements at EU level.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, we need to hold our governments and our businesses accountable for the way they engage with other countries, especially when it comes to preserving natural resources. Indigenous people’s rights, and in particular land rights, are almost systematically overlooked. Last December in Kenya, the Sengwer community faced a wave of forced evictions from their ancestral land, despite the fact that their forest is included in the water conservation programme financed by the EU, and some Sengwer were killed in the eviction process. The EU temporarily suspended its funding and now we need to continue engaging with the Kenyan authorities on the ground to ensure full accountability for the human rights violations that occurred. It is also important that the EU delegation in Nairobi doesn’t let the current negotiations drag on, as many people’s livelihoods depend on the viability of this project. We need to keep this experience in mind in order to ensure that human rights due diligence, in particular when it comes to indigenous rights, remain at the heart of any future EU engagement with other countries.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, it has been a great honour to draw up an opinion on this report by the ENVI Committee. In this context, I would like to commend the work of all the shadow rapporteurs and the excellent cooperation with Mrs Hautala. I am really very glad that the European Parliament is not afraid to talk about the subject of deforestation, but it is really high time for the Commission to act. The Commission has been waiting a long time for independent studies, which ultimately unsurprisingly declared that the EU is clearly part of the problem of global deforestation. Honourable Commission, now that you finally know what you should have known a long time ago, please also know this: by the end of this mandate, we expect the Commission to present an ambitious EU action plan on deforestation and forest degradation, containing concrete regulatory measures. I know this is going to be difficult, but it was you who was wasting your time while the rainforests were disappearing or being burned because of the demand for biofuels in the European Union.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, the Hautala report makes a good observation but is wrong about remedies. Globalization is the problem, not the solution. Trying to repair it with green regulatory patches does not prevent its destructive logic. The only real solution is to give up this absurd free trade of the global single market based on price competition. The massive importation of wood and its processing outside our environmental and social standards in China and Vietnam is the real source of deforestation, and the report does not address it. 75% of timber exports go to China, as well as French woods. Ecological agriculture is also the best way to combat deforestation of primary forests, but it also calls for protectionism in developing countries and in our country, and these standards are absent from this report. We will therefore vote against this report, despite its good intentions.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, deforestation, degradation and illegal logging can also be motivated by trade-related factors. That is why the European Union's trade policy has a vital role to play. The European Union is one of the main exporters and importers of goods. It therefore has the opportunity to act at the level of international standards, contrary to what our colleague from the radical right has said. But more than a will, it is an obligation. Indeed, the European Court of Justice has said, in its opinion on Singapore, that the European Union must integrate the objectives of preserving and improving the quality of the environment and sustainable management of resources within the framework of its trade policy. So what to do? First, to have a regulatory framework for enforcing transparency obligations throughout the supply of risky forest products; second, to strengthen the sustainable development chapter with sanction mechanisms. So fighting climate change with voluntary measures is simply irresponsible. That is why I appeal to the sense of responsibility of all of us in this Parliament, not to support the separate votes of some Members of this Parliament, which would go totally to suicide in relation to climate respect.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission welcomes this opportunity today to discuss the challenges forests face in a global context of increased pressure on natural resources. The Commission welcomes the report and warmly thanks the rapporteur, Vice-President Heidi Hautala, for the excellent work undertaken. Forests are nature’s most generous renewable resources. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the new European Consensus on Development have reaffirmed the urgency to tackle illegal and unsustainable exploitation of forests by supporting better governance. In this endeavour, transparency and accountability – two elements highlighted by this report –show a way forward. As far as the Commission is concerned, we are strongly committed to tackling illegal logging and trade, and promoting good governance in the forestry sector. Through the EU flagship initiative the Forest Law-enforcement, Governance and Trade Action Plan, we have put forward a comprehensive toolkit to tackle both the illegal production of timber and its consumption. This year marks the first 15 years, so let me briefly recall the significant achievements of the forest action plan. A key element is the new Timber Regulation. I am pleased to confirm that after more than five years of implementation, there is steady progress in its enforcement. In 2009, the EU concluded its first voluntary partnership agreement with Ghana. As of today, we count 15 agreements, and we recently initiated an agreement with Honduras, and we hope to close this year with Guyana and Vietnam. Voluntary partnership agreements have been the cornerstone of the forest action plan. An important proof of this is Indonesia which in November 2016 became the first country to export timber to the EU that was licensed through the action plan. Since then, Indonesia has issued close to 40 000 licenses with a total value of more than USD 1 billion. That is about 25% of tropical timber imports into the European Union. Forest law-enforcement, governance and trade and licensing are a significant milestone yet it is only the end of a long journey that involves overall governance improvement, as we see in Ghana. And, most importantly the benefits go beyond forests, contributing to larger EU initiatives such as the protection of indigenous people’s rights and environmental defenders. The Forest Law-Enforcement, Governance and Trade initiative owes part of its success to the engagement of the private sector as you have already said. New alliances are necessary, including with big consumer countries, especially China, and with financial institutions. The Commission is currently concluding the Forest Law-Enforcement, Governance and Trade work plan for the period 2018-2022, and the European Union has also included environmental crime linked to forests in the priorities of its overall fight against organised crime for 2018-2021. In the end, I would like to say that the Commission hears your call for more measures to halt deforestations. The EU is already doing a lot through the forest flagship initiative I just mentioned, through the mechanism of the reduced emissions from deforestation and degradation. We will draw the lessons but more needs to be done. Deforestation is a complex matter requiring a specific approach that involves all the relevant stakeholders, not least in partner countries. We therefore intend to pursue a high level of ambition in the next Multiannual Financial Framework, including through our broad neighbourhood development and international cooperation instruments. It will seek to mainstream environmental protection in a geographical pillar and complement this by targeted thematic actions on sustainable forest management, illegal logging and conflict timber. We look forward to your support.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Tuesday 11 September 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – We all know that forests are the lungs of the world, but then why do we treat them so badly that we deforestation, burn them, cut them illegally? They contribute significantly to climate change mitigation and adaptation and biodiversity conservation. They prevent land degradation and desertification, thereby reducing the risk of floods, landslides and droughts. They are essential for sustainable agriculture and improve food security and nutrition.  It is for these and many other reasons that I voted for the Report on transparent and responsible management of natural resources in developing countries! This Report asks the EU to support the integration of forest and land management objectives into the ESC contributions of forest-rich developing countries, and recalls that the Paris Agreement requires all parties to take measures to preserve and improve sinks, including forests.  Deforestation and destruction of forests is not any way of lying well towards this natural resource, and at the same time illegal logging and wood trade is one of the five most important sectors of environmental crime. I strongly advocate fostering participatory and joint forest management by increasing the involvement of civil society in the planning and implementation of forest management policies and projects, raising awareness and ensuring that local communities also benefit from forest resources.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: Writing. – This debate on forest reforestation outside the EU makes a hopeless sigh about what is happening in the forests of our countries.  The fact that there was twice as many forests in Estonia 100 years ago shows that our organisation and ethics of forest management have not been sustainable. That's just the last decade. For hundreds of years, estonians worked to make the swamp fields and the scrubbed woodland - today our forest becomes one of the most vast cuttings in the conduct of state institutions.  We should put an end to the hypocritical practice of producing renewable energy by burning wood in cauldrons and, more importantly, to marketing it as an environmentally friendly energy source to other countries that had a lower share of renewable energy than expected. Not to mention its environmental impact, the burning of high-quality wood into ash also has its own economic damage factor: this wood could be used more sustainably in another sector, but also at a higher profit. It is also inexcusable that logging is sloppy in national parks and in valuable green areas, where it should meet the requirements of strict supervision and transparency. The 12th edition of the journal "Eesti Mets" reads that "it is true that christians who are handing out the kingdom in the Riigikogu are many willing and converged again. Not knowing what kind of party will share the sea?" More than political parties, state agencies are responsible for unbalanced logging in estonia today, which act contrary to their ds.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Krzysztof Hetman, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on increasing economic growth and cohesion in the EU's border regions (2018/2054(INI)) (A8-0266/2018).

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The internal border regions of the European Union account for forty percent of its territory and are inhabited by one hundred and fifty million people. Unfortunately, they still face numerous specific problems that make them perform worse than regions within countries. Their economic potential is not fully exploited. I am pleased that the European Commission has recognised this problem and has carried out an examination of these legal and administrative barriers and a public consultation resulting in a communication on increasing economic growth and cohesion in the border regions of the European Union, identifying ten main obstacles and proposing solutions to these problems. However, I would like to stress that I consider it particularly important to carry out a similar review for the regions at the external borders. Indeed, we must bear in mind that the solutions proposed in the review currently under discussion cannot, in many cases, be easily transferred to these regions. This is due to their very different specificities, such as the absence of the Schengen area, the non-share of the common market and many others. I would therefore like to ask the Commission to prepare a separate analysis for both the external regions and the maritime regions. I am convinced that mutual trust and political will of all competent authorities, including local and regional authorities in particular, is the most powerful tool for overcoming the burden on the development of border regions. This requires both flexibility and sometimes specific rules to ensure consistency between different legal systems, as often even the same directive is transposed differently in two neighbouring countries. It should therefore be emphasised that a number of urgent issues require more targeted intensive action at both Member State and European Union level to enable local authorities to cooperate more effectively. Cross-border workers must have recognised qualifications and should be well informed of their social security. Barriers to cross-border entrepreneurs should also be removed, as cross-border businesses currently have sixty per cent higher costs than companies operating in one country. I would like to draw attention to the huge positive role played by the European Territorial Cooperation programmes in overcoming barriers. I would like to express my full support for their continuation, or indeed their strengthening after 2021. Interreg is a program that, thanks to a bottom-up approach, has proven its effectiveness in establishing cooperation, among others, in the fields of health, education, environmental protection, and has also contributed to building trust between local communities on both sides of the border. While appreciating the role of the Cross-Border Cooperation Programme, I would also like to draw attention to the potential of European territorial cooperation groups. I am convinced that, thanks to this instrument, we are able to overcome many of the problems that border regions currently face.  I also believe that we should boldly deepen cross-border cooperation, which is why I consider it necessary and justified to strengthen new tools for managing cross-border cooperation. Finally, I would like to stress that I am pleased that the Commission has set up a coordination point for cross-border cases. I believe that it will be an effective tool for national and regional authorities to deal with legal or administrative obstacles at the borders.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, cross-border regions are an essential part of European territory, and a third of European citizens live in these regions. However, they suffer from development obstacles, and the problems they face are generally common. A framework of measures is therefore needed to facilitate the exploitation of this potential by removing obstacles and exploiting existing advantages. Firstly, the mobility of workers across borders is an important factor in the development of cooperation, and Member States, through regional authorities, are obliged to facilitate the free movement of workers in these regions. Lack of connectivity is another aspect that prevents the isation of cross-border activities, and the authorities in these regions are responsible for contributing solutions to complement the missing links in transport networks. Regional authorities should do more to encourage entrepreneurship in cross-border regions by creating common electronic portals for economic activities on both sides of borders. Territorial cooperation programmes provide significant support to cross-border regions and regional authorities have the opportunity to make the most of these forms of support.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, you are one of the members of the Commission who knows very well the issue of regional development and cohesion funds. Of course, much has been done in cross-border trade and economic development, but the rapporteur has put forward here some proposals with which I fully agree. Firstly, we need to simplify procedures - for cross-border employment, labour mobility. New small and medium-sized enterprises will be able to develop, which in turn is creating jobs and, ultimately, bringing a profit to the budget of those countries and, obviously, to the budget of the European Union. I think it depends, of course, very much on the Member States, but it would not hurt to come up with experience from the Commission, with a procedure, with an example, and to try to increase the funds that are allocated for cross-border economic development, because – it has been said here – a good part of the citizens of the European Union live in these areas. And, yes, I agree to find means for external borders, not just internal borders. Perhaps once and for all Romania and Bulgaria will be in the Schengen area, so that we do not have two internal markets.

name: Aleksander GABELIC
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Creţu, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent Cohesion policy is close to people. Together, European regions build infrastructures, create growth and provide the conditions for greener innovation. The cross-border cooperation of European regions is a concrete example of the great added value of European cooperation. Of course, therefore, we should safeguard lessons and good examples from European regions now that the new programming period is being negotiated. It is therefore difficult to understand why the Commission wants to unravel the current structure of cohesion policy. Like the Commission, I believe that we should have an effective Europe and I see the usefulness of existing cooperation that today facilitates commuters through common transport networks, such as between Tallinn and Helsinki, or which brings young people together through transregional youth networks. The Commission's proposal to place regional cooperation at the maritime border under transnational programmes is therefore worrying, as examples such as these may be lost.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Membră a Comisiei. – Mulțumesc foarte mult pentru această dezbatere. Este un subiect care îmi este foarte aproape de suflet. S-au spus foarte multe aici, dar, dincolo de avantajele cooperării transfrontaliere în ceea ce privește crearea de locuri de muncă, creșterea economică, având în vedere posibilitățile de dezvoltare, eu văd și un alt rol al cooperării transfrontaliere mai important decât orice, acela de a vindeca rănile pe care încă le avem pe harta Uniunii Europene, pe harta continentului nostru. Am început dezbaterea din această seară cu raportul privind beneficiile politicii de coeziune în Irlanda de Nord, un caz foarte clar în care vedem cât de greu se construiește pacea și cât de ușor se poate pierde. În cei aproape 4 ani de când sunt comisar european pentru politică regională am vizitat foarte multe proiecte transfrontaliere și am fost foarte emoționată, de pildă, când am vizitat proiecte dintre Polonia și Germania, între Šlovice și Frankfurt(Oder), de asemenea între Bratislava și Austria de jos și alte proiecte în jurul granițelor, unde acum aproape 30 de ani au murit atâtea mii de oameni în căutarea unei vieți mai bune. De aceea, facem tot ce putem și am făcut tot ce am putut în această perioadă pentru a îmbunătăți această cooperare transfrontalieră, care uneori merge foarte ușor, în ciuda diferențelor de limbă, alteori, cum este cazul între Belgia și Franța de pildă, deși e aceeași limbă, din cauza faptului că cele două țări nu se înțeleg să adopte o legislație comună în cooperarea transfrontalieră, aceasta este mai greoaie. De asemenea, sunt întristată să văd câte proiecte transfrontaliere sunt blocate din cauza orgoliilor unor state. În fond și la urma urmei, acest program Interreg și de cooperare transfrontalieră a fost creat pentru a îmbunătăți comunicarea dintre oameni. Suntem în septembrie 2018 și foarte multe dintre proiectele de cooperare transfrontalieră dintre statele membre sunt blocate, banii sunt necheltuiți pentru că statele membre nu se înțeleg în privința proiectelor asupra cărora să cheltuiască acești bani. I will continue in English. Thank you very much for this enriching debate. I would also like to thank the rapporteur for this report and for what I see as a very positive approach towards the Commission’s initiative in favour of European border regions. I of course share this assessment of the situation faced by border regions and the call for continued attention to be paid to them.  As I said, this is what the Commission is doing. Since the adoption of the communication on border regions in September last year, a number of concrete measures have already been initiated. I have in mind, in particular, the border focal point that was established in January 2018 and is now operational. It coordinates action between the Commission services responsible, but also has a mission to liaise and interact with external stakeholders. This hands—on approach has been reinforced with the launch of online exchange platforms for border stakeholders and institutions, and we have also recently selected ten pilot projects to identify ways in which certain legal and administrative obstacles can be resolved. Besides, we have been carrying out targeted work on specific cross—border issues, be it a recent study on missing rail links, a merging of cross—border healthcare or a regional border workshop for businesses and citizens.  All this work mirrors the Commission’s commitment to ensuring that no region is left behind. It also underpins our proposal for the next programming period. As you know, a new legal instrument to resolve border obstacles was proposed by the Commission on 29 May 2018 and is currently being considered by Member States and in Parliament in the relevant committees. The draft proposals for the Interreg Programmes post—2020 also contain elements that will facilitate the prevention and lifting of border obstacles. Notably, it is proposed that each cross—border cooperation programme dedicates at least 15% of its budget to institutional cooperation, including the resolution of legal and administrative issues. Member States will, of course, continue to have a strong role to play in this process. The Commission will support them in their endeavour to improve the socio—economic development of their border regions by making good practices widely available and by ensuring that future cross—border cooperation programmes are tailored to the specific needs of border regions. To conclude, allow me to make a specific call both to the Council and to you, the European Parliament. I know you were working very hard on our budgetary proposal over the summer, but it is crucial to progress as speedily as possible. Indeed, the future generation of cross—border programmes and the new legal instrument to resolve border obstacles are crucial to further growth and cohesion in our internal border region.  Thank you very much for having this important subject on our agenda. Hopefully we will have the Multiannual Financial Framework as soon as possible in order to be able to start the implementation of the programmes from the first day of the new programming period, from 1 January 2021. We should draw from the lesson that we have now of all the operational programmes in the project being so delayed due to the late adoption of the legislation for the programming period 2014—2020.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you, Commissioner, for those hours spent with us. If you would like to stay with us further, please.  I close the debate. The vote will take place on Tuesday 11 September 2018.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
