name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Mr President, on 27 August the Danish company Vestas announced the closure of its Villadangos del Páramo plant. I'm talking about the abolition of five hundred direct and two thousand indirect jobs. The closure gives a hard blow to a Lioness region whose economy and employment depend mostly on the plant. In addition, the region is greatly affected by aging and depopulation. Vestas has benefited from public aid through ERDF funds. The closure and transfer of production to non-EU countries involves the fraudulent use of these Union funds , thirteen million. And the Union must monitor, penalize and demand the repayment of subsidies. It is vital to ensure production-related jobs. Any solution must go through an agreement with workers that does not undermine their employment, remuneration and geographical situation. We reject, as unlawful, the ERE launched. In addition, we will ask the Commission to denounce this repeated situation before the Court of Justice of the European Union. Vestas cannot and should not be closed, Mr. President.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Mr President, I said that Europe is a way: whether it is the roads of the Roman roads, the pilgrimage routes or the cultural paths; but also digital networks and railway tracks. That is why I would like to conclude the European Commission's decision to include, albeit with some delay, Asturias within the framework of the trans-European transport networks, within the Atlantic Corridor. I would therefore like to ask this House and the Council to deal quickly with this position because we need to include the whole of northwestern Spain within the heart of Europe, and also to bridge the Atlantic world. With the unanimous voice of a small region, Asturias, I ask you to allow us to build that Europe of all that is asking for civil society very actively in my small region, in my dear Asturias.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by One of the most basic forms of prevention of many diseases is washing hands with running warm soapy water. There has been no hot water in the tap in the European Parliament since July 2016, since I was re-elected, although the toilets have been hung with detailed information on how to wash my hands. Given that people work and live in parliament not only from all over Europe, but even from different parts of the world, and even assuming that everyone is healthy, they can nevertheless be carriers of various diseases. In addition, assistants wash dishes in toilets also with cold water, which rivals the basic principles of prevention, as a risk factor for the transmission of various diseases. At the beginning of my term of office, I asked the Vice-President about the situation because hygiene conditions have not changed. I renew the question for the sake of prevention of the health of the guests working and staying here.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Thank you very much, Mr President. The efforts Macedonian and Greek governments have done regarding the name-related issues are enormous. Just try to imagine how we would react if Luxembourg has been asked to change its name because there is a province of Luxembourg in Belgium. And just try to imagine how we would react if Luxembourg accepted to do it. We would certainly think the demand was almost ridiculous. We would certainly think that Luxembourg has sacrificed itself to the limit of implosion and it showed extreme will to compromise. The Greek and Macedonian government have found this difficult compromise now. They have found a solution, overbridging emotional, historical and identity issues on both sides and they have to be helped to finalise the issue. Years have been lost in this conflict and we cannot afford to prolong it. People from both countries have to show maturity to finalise this deal. They have to have the audacity to believe that another future might be possible, and we have to help them in that.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, Spain is an exception in Europe. It is the only European country that has not yet been able to judge its dictatorship today. After forty years of democracy, Francoism in our country has not yet been judged. We are an exception in Europe, because we are the second country in the world with the greatest number of missing in our ditches, as in the Mass graves of Paterna that we were able to visit last Friday; an exception in Europe because we have not been able to judge our torturers, who walk our streets with medals. We don't want their medals taken away. We want to be judged. We want Francoist in our country to be judged after forty years of democracy; that forty years of democracy will serve not only to take Franco out of the Valley of the Fallen, but above all to take Francoism out of our institutions.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, the parliamentary elections in Sweden are a further warning for the European Union. By winning almost 20% of the vote, the nationalists have become key players in Swedish political life. It is above all the refusal of migratory submersion that explains their breakthrough. I myself went to Sweden and saw how much mass immigration has become a problem there. It is not surprising that there has been a democratic surge. The European Union must listen to the message of the Swedish people and stop locking itself in the ivory tower of its unbridled globalism. The peoples of Europe want secure borders, not the sieve that has become the Schengen area. It is Matteo Salvini and Marine Le Pen who are now their spokespersons, not Jean-Claude Juncker and Emmanuel Macron. Listen to them - while there is still time - and transform the European Union into a Europe of Nations with us. Otherwise, the whole of European construction will disappear.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, there is no more cynical mockery than the celebrations of the SYRIZA-ANEL government that the memoranda in Greece are over. No memorandum law is repealed. Some little crumbs in extreme poverty simply justify new privileges in capital. Supervision intensifies and assures markets and investors that the sacrifice of the people holds well, that they can invest profitably. New pension carnage and tax evasion with a reduction in the tax-free; bloody surpluses for decades ahead and, of course always, permanent financial regulations and supervision of the Union; regulations that exude even barbarism and cannibalism, for example, the report that you will be asked to vote on tomorrow and which regards the disability and illness of the worker as an unacceptable cost to the company and requires work even for the disabled , until the end of the fall. The memoranda of the European Union and the governments have come to stay, if the people do not rip them off with their struggle, if they do not abolish the main culprits for them: its capital and profits and its political power.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European As a citizen of the Slovak Republic, I would like to draw attention to the importance of respecting the basic political and moral rules of the game. The public in Slovakia was shocked a few months ago by the brutal murder of a journalist and his fiancee in our country, in the middle of Europe. A few weeks ago, another shocking news emerged that the Communist government of Vietnam had used the official aircraft of the Slovak government to smuggle a Vietnamese citizen out of the Schengen zone, with the Slovak side also deceithing the Polish authorities.  And if that is not enough, we received the news a few days ago that the EU anti-corruption office OLAF had discovered a fraud of more than EUR 300 million in Slovakia, in which the Slovak customs authorities knowingly undervalued Chinese goods imported into the EU in order to impose much lower duties on them.  Mr President, I am very sorry that my country is inging such negative news, and I would like to say, at the request of my constituents, that there are many of us in Slovakia who do not agree with these practices. Thank you very much!

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Mr President, African swine fever is causing significant damage to European breeders in Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Ukraine, Romania and Bulgaria. According to figures released by the National Veterinary Sanitary and Food Safety Authority, eleven counties are currently affected in Romania, with 826 outbreaks of fish, and the number of animals slaughtered has reached 159,645 heads. I would like to draw attention and a wake-up call, at the same time, about the danger of drastically reducing pig herds in Europe because of this disease, which risks affecting the food security of the citizens of the European Union, which is why I believe that the European executive must take measures to activate the reserve funds necessary for rapid intervention in the affected states. I remind you that if a Member State has a problem, it means that the whole Union is facing the same problem. I therefore believe that the European Union should be more involved in this situation.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the European project was, at the beginning, a round table around which equal nations were to stand. Subsequently, the idea of a superstate arose, where effective power was exercised by over-servants and Member States became a kind of province surge d'Iatia and asphalting the streets. The round table has therefore become rectangular. Recently, the idea of Europe has been issued at a higher rate. I imagine that on a postage we will have a table with armchairs, below some benches like the cafeteria, and in the back and some standing seats for those who will applaud. At the previous State of the Union speech, the President of the Commission promised us reform. In the spring, he presented us with five scenarios for the future. Since then, no one has talked about reform, and "Europe with more speeds" seems to be the scenario based on "the fulfilled fact". I'm in a straight line towards the end of this warrant. Not for our prestige, but for the fate of the European project, we owe it to ourselves to decide transparently what we want to become. A key to the Union's survival is neither concentration of power nor segregation on geographical grounds. A prosperous Union must be based on the democratic empowerment of nations for a common future.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, I want to raise the issue of the Irish humanitarian worker, Sean Binder, and the Syrian rescue swimmer, Sarah Mardini, who at this moment are sitting in separate Greek prisons accused of actions related to their aid work in Greece. These two young people have been working on the island of Lesbos for the last few months for one of the many grassroots organisations based in southern Europe who have had to step into the gap left by the failure of European leaders to provide protection for vulnerable migrants arriving through perilous routes across the Mediterranean. This arrest, and others like it, has exposed pervasive efforts to put a chill on civil society volunteers working to prevent deaths at sea and give medical assistance and education to those lucky enough to reach a place they see as safe. Sean and Sarah, who herself fled the conflict in Syria, should not be sitting in cells. They should be lauded for their courage and compassion for their life-saving work. Tonight I ask the European Parliament to join with me in calling for the immediate release of both Sean and Sarah from detention while the investigation is still ongoing, and for an urgent political response against the criminalisation of humanitarian workers.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Territorial autonomy is one of the EU's values, but there are countries that stifle such aspirations. In Romania, the state rejects even the suggestion of the autonomy of szeklerland, which is inhabited by mostly Hungarians, and is increasingly threatening the Hungarian population.  Recently, the court rulings of István Beke and Zoltán Szőcs provoked an outcry: the Bucharest Board Court imposed on them a prison sentence of less than one year for crimes committed by pyrotechnics, which had already been served in investigative captivity. At the same time, the high court un evidenced that they had been converted into an act of terrorism and sentenced them to five years in prison. The European Parliament regularly deals with individual human rights violations in different parts of the world this week. It is time to discuss such cases in our Member States. Thank you, Mr. President.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I express my opposition to two cases reminiscent of the Ceausescu dictatorship, and I call on the support of this House and the President on these matters. As I indicated at the beginning of July, nearly three decades after the fall of the nationalist regime, Hungarian political prisoners are again suffering prison sentences in Romania. István Beke and Zoltán Szőcs were sentenced to five years in prison on trumped-up charges, without evidence, in order to intimidate Hungarians. The emergency government decree entrusting the teaching of Romanian language and literature to Romanian teachers who do not know Hungarian in Hungarian primary schools in order to spoil hungarian language education is also reminiscent of the anti-Hungarian Communist era. This brutal measure, in its own way, is in accordance with the anti-minority Ukrainian Education Act. Please come to the defense of the Hungarians in Transylvania.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to refer to the recent statement by the Vice-President of the Commission, Commissioner Oettinger. To me, it is surprising that a high dignitary, a high representative of the Commission, in a public space, in an official meeting, accuses and announces the danger of death of the European Union because of some Member States, including my country, Romania. Of course I was asked at home what was going on, what are the reasons why the Commissioner puts on the list of the four Member States and Romania. Romania, as we know, is a pro-European country. We are at the top of the countries with citizens who want the European project. I want and ask this explanation to the Commissioner, to tell the citizens why Romania wants to destroy the European Union. I was among the leading countries to participate in frontex, in all programmes initiated by the European Union. Which is the Commissioner's reason – and I think it was inappropriate for the Commissioner to express his expression, not to say irresponsible, now that we are in the run-up to the election, only if he is campaigning. The European elections are coming up, and we really need unity in the European Union.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Monitoring Centre for Freedom of the Press – a Polish social college composed of outstanding journalistic authorities, with a long history, great merit for defending media freedom – expressed its very serious concern about the discussion, the voices that have been raised in the Belgian Administrative Board RTBF – Belgian public television, on the removal of the transmission of the Catholic Mass from public broadcasting. The greatest consternation is raised by the motives of these statements, namely that on the last Sunday of August, the fifth chapter of the letter to The Ephesians of St. Paul was read in the majority of catholic churches in the world, describing the ideals of Christian marriage.  Well, for those politicians on the Administrative Board of the RTBF, this is i cannot be reconciled with their gender criteria – this unfortunately shows how serious a threat freedom has been in many European countries today. I thank the Polish journalists for defending it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, it is the entitlement and birthright of all of us born on the island of Ireland to be part of the Irish nation. Article 2 of Bunreacht na hÉireann defines citizenship as ‘a right to rights’, and the right to democratic participation is a crucial element of citizenship. The north of Ireland should continue to have representatives here post-Brexit. Legal advice by barrister Mark Bassett demonstrates that it is legally possible and permissible for a dedicated Ireland North constituency to be established, and for the two additional MEP seats to be allocated to the north by the Oireachtas, simply by adopting a wider provision in the European Parliament Act 1997. Out of 28 Member States, 22 afford nationals not resident in their Member State the right to vote in European Parliament elections. Currently, Ireland deprives those of us living outside the jurisdiction of the state that right. With only 200 days before Brexit, no matter what its shade, the people of the north must suffer most. The Good Friday Agreement will be undermined and the decision taken by the EU will continue to impact all of us after Brexit, so strong voices will be needed here in the European Parliament post-Brexit.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Mr President, I have heard Mr Verhofstadt and Mr Bullmann on many occasions criticise the Hungarian and Polish governments. Rightly – I too believe that Orban and Kaczyński are opponents of the rule of law. But perhaps it would be good for Mr Verhofstadt and Mr Bullmann to also look to Romania, where the parties they have twinned with, the PSD and the ALDE, are making a mess. I do not think that Mr Bullmann and Mr Verhofstadt like what, in the name of liberalism and socialism, is happening in Romania: the destruction of the independence of the judiciary, the assault by means of force and tear gas of peaceful protesters, the public lynching of opponents of the current power, the political partisan confiscation of the state. I recommend to Mr Verhofstadt and Mr Bullmann to exclude the PSD and THE ALDE from their political groups, because the place of the parties of Mr Dragnea and Mr Tariceanu is with populists and radicals. No one in Romania understands how the socialist and liberal family supports people, politicians who go directly, explicitly against the rule of law, directly and explicitly against the European Commission and the European institutions. The place of these parties is, unfortunately, with radicals and populists.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, penguins can have a tough time in the Falklands because of unlicensed egg collecting, invasive diseases, fishing and getting covered in oil. But now there’s another problem hatching – Brexit. Brexit has left the UK overseas territories in a flap, as the islands stand to lose millions in funding from EU conservation projects. Five projects in the South Atlantic are currently funded by the Best scheme, which runs until December 2019. It also means goodbye to LIFE funding, which issues grants of up to four and a half million pounds. I often say that no one who voted for Brexit, voted to lose their job or to damage the NHS, or for lower food standards or fewer rights at work. The list goes on and on. And today I add to it that no one who voted for Brexit, voted to harm penguins. Hard Tory Brexit means a million penguins, and our nation, risk being left out in the cold.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Today is the start of school in several Member States. In Romania, a ministerial decree was drafted a few days before the start of school, which will make significant changes for primary school children studying minority languages: from now on, they will have to learn the language of the state not from their teacher, but from specialist teachers in higher schools who do not even know the mother tongue of young children.  It is impossible to put the regulation into effect in the absence of a sufficient number of staff, but without any professional or political consultation, the Minister of Education has put thousands of primary school children in a completely unknown and foreign situation. This is not only an untrusted and malicious decision, it deeply offends children studying minority languages, their parents and well-prepared educators.  This type of decision-making process is typical of the Romanian authorities, which not only do not carry out an impact assessment, but also do not consult the stakeholders when taking similar decisions. The only solution may be to withdraw the regulation and apologise to those affected.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Creu, legislative elections took place yesterday in an important country of the European Union: Sweden. Once again, dominated by an issue that is no secret to anyone: migration.  Exactly the same thing happened in the Austrian elections, in the French elections, in the German elections, in the Italian elections, but above all they have been dominated by a European policy flaw in an area that requires 'Europe' like no other, even more so than the euro or that of foreign policy. Because the euro is not shared as currency by all the Member States of the European Union, nor is foreign policy structured cooperation involving all Member States. On the other hand, the concern for migration is, but it is especially concerned with the absence of a European response. Firstly, to change the European Union's negative view of the migration phenomenon, thinking distically that zero migration can be achieved, by denying the phenomenon or by closing the floodgates.  But secondly, we must change the non-European view, which refuses to share responsibility. It is therefore still an urgent urgency for the Council to unlock the Dublin Regulation and establish a channel, a shared responsibility and the channel for humanitarian visas so that those trying to reach the European Union do not lose their lives in the attempt.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, Europe is facing a migration crisis and we are all carrying its political consequences, which are reflected in the results of the elections, as my speaker mentioned, in Sweden, but also in the unrest, for example in Sask. In addition to migration from Africa, it is mainly the regime of Bashar Assad, who has driven 14 million people from their homes in Syria, more than 6 million of them beyond Syria's borders, with the help of Putin.  Now another attack is under way against the insurgents' last bastion in Idlíb. So there is a risk of further killing of civilians. The international community should respond, and I ask if it can prevent this evil. Can we help those who suffer innocently? And these are mainly child victims of war, they are orphans. I very much wish that we could do this and that among those who will help children without parents in Europe is also the Czech Republic.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I rise to demonstrate the solidarity of this House with everyone affected by natural disasters over the summer period, but, as First Vice—President of the Delegation for Relations with India, I want to highlight the plight of the people of Kerala. Over the summer, devastating flooding has killed more than 500 people, more than a million people have been displaced, and more than 169 medical facilities, including hospitals, have been damaged. Although some people have been able to return to their homes from the relief camps, the water has not receded and the risk of waterborne diseases is high. Cases of rat fever have been reported in five districts. I welcome the EU’s support to the Indian Red Cross for immediate relief assistance, but it is imperative that greater support is made available for building medical facilities. All over the globe we have witnessed the effects of climate change. Therefore, I call for urgent implementation of the EU-India Clean Energy and Climate Partnership. This has to be prioritised by the Commission.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Presidential and parliamentary elections will be held in Ukraine in 2019. The campaign has already started, with European and Euro-Atlantic integration, European values and reforms an important element. Nevertheless, to date, the Ukrainian Parliament has not adopted a new single electoral code, renewed the Central Election Commission, which already has expired in 2014, and has not created a clean and level playing field for the representation of national minorities in the country.   In 2014, the Ukrainian Central Election Commission re-tailored individual constituencies in Transcarpathia without taking into account the current law according to which the boundaries of administrative units, the interests of local communities and national minorities in the area should be taken into account when forming individual constituencies.  I hope that the European Parliament will not only monitor the elections in Ukraine, but will also speak out on discriminatory and illegal measures such as in 2014, when they prevented the Hungarian community in Transcarpathia from inging an individual representative to the Supreme Council. Ukraine must not narrow the existing rights of national minorities, it must guarantee the access of minority representatives to their legislative, advocacy and municipal bodies, as this is one of the main criteria for the rule of law. Thank you!

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in 1908, 110 years ago, a terrible earthquake destroyed Messina, causing more than 80 000 deaths. For the 40,000 survivors, huts were built, which were obviously emergency. I know it sounds incredible to you, but today in Messina, 110 years after what was europe's worst disaster in the number of victims, 6 400 people are still living in shacks. Interventions and recovery plans that have never been implemented have allowed the emergency to continue, and today it is even aggravated, because the roof of those shacks is asbestos, a deadly substance banned by Europe twenty years ago because it is carcinogenic. What is new is that there are now people who have fallen ill with asbestosis, a terrible disease that consumes the lungs of those who breathe asbestos, for which there is no cure. Messina, a great Sicilian city, is Europe, although you wouldn't say that to see those shacks. The mayor has ordered the eviction, but there are no houses for everyone. We must now think about people's health, and I, together with the Council Group of the Democratic Party of Messina, are calling for Europe to intervene, for the intervention of health commissioner Andriukaitis and Commissioner Crețu, and for no one to breathe that terrible substance, asbestos, which kills yet.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – First of all, I thank the European Commission for its decision to accommodate millions of Citizens of the Union and to abolish the rotation of time twice a year. However, I would like to take this opportunity to ask Commissioner Bulc to publish the draft relevant legislation as soon as possible. I am already faced with questions from citizens, the media, even some colleagues, to whom it is not clear what the abolition of time rotation will actually mean. Some expect daylight saving time to be retained throughout the year, others quite the opposite. I have also encountered the fear that harmonisation will be abolished altogether, which would mean chaos. It took several years to get to this stage of negotiation. It would be detrimental if inaccurate information or lack thereof created uncertainty and misunderstanding in society. I therefore appeal to the Commission to communicate clearly and unequivocally on this issue.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the discussion on this item on the agenda.
